Numerous real-world aircraft have appeared in [[fiction]] over the decades, including in books, films, toys, TV programs, video games and other media. These appearances spotlight the popularity of different models of aircraft, and showcase the different models for the general public.
The years between [[World War I]] and [[World War II]] saw extensive use of the new technology, aircraft, in the new medium, film.<ref>Wohl, p. 112</ref> In the early 1920s Hollywood studios made dozens of now-obscure 'aerial Westerns' with leads such as [[Tom Mix]] and [[Hoot Gibson]], where the role of the horse was taken by aircraft, or used aircraft as nothing more than vehicles for stunts to excite audiences.<ref>Wohl, p. 113</ref> In 1926 the first 'proper' aviation film was made; ''[[Wings (film)|Wings]]'' is a story of two pilots who sign up to fly and fight in World War I.<ref>Wohl, p. 114</ref> Made with the co-operation of the then-[[United States Department of War|Department of War]] (a relationship that continues to this day), it used front-line military aircraft of the day such as the [[Thomas-Morse MB-3]] and [[Boeing Model 15|Boeing PW-9]], flown by military pilots.<ref name="aerofiles">{{cite web |url= http://aerofiles.net/film-u.html |title= List of aviation films (U to Z) |last= aerofiles.com |first= |authorlink= |year= |accessdate= 2010-01-16}}</ref><ref>Wohl, p. 117</ref> Future United States Air Force Generals [[Henry H. Arnold|Hap Arnold]] and [[Hoyt Vandenberg]] were among the military officers involved with the production, Arnold as a technical consultant and Vandenberg as one of the pilots.<ref name="tcmWings">{{cite web |url= http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title.jsp?stid=504086&category=Notes |title= ''Wings'' (1927) - notes on the production |accessdate= 2010-01-17 |last= Turner Classic Movies |authorlink= |year= 2010}}</ref> ''Wings'' was a box-office hit when it achieved general release in 1929 and went on the win the award for Best Production at the first [[Academy Award]]s.<ref>Wohl, p. 115</ref><ref name="Oscars">{{cite web |url= http://www.filmsite.org/bestpics3.html |title= List of Academy Award winners for Best Picture |last= filmsite.org |authorlink= |year= 2009 |accessdate= 2010-01-16 }}</ref>
In [[Italian Fascism|Fascist Italy]] in the 1930s, aviation-themed films were used as [[propaganda]] tools to complement the massed flights led by [[Italo Balbo]] in promoting the regime domestically and abroad.<ref>Wohl, p. 93</ref><ref name="W109">Wohl, p. 109</ref> One such film was the most successful Italian film of the pre-World War II era. ''Luciano Serra pilota'' (''Luciano Serra, pilot'') was inextricably linked to the Fascist government via [[Benito Mussolini|Mussolini's]] son [[Vittorio Mussolini|Vittorio]], who was the driving force behind the film's production.<ref name="W109"/> The film, set between the year 1921 and the [[Second Italo-Abyssinian War|Italo-Abyssinian War]], was used to compare the allegedly-moribund state of aviation in pre-Fascist Italy with the purported power of the [[Regia Aeronautica]] and Italian aviation in general in the 1930s.<ref>Wohl, pp. 109-112</ref> However, by the time that ''Luciano Serra pilota'' was shown at the 1938 [[Venice Film Festival]], the link between aviation and Fascism had already been firmly established in the minds of the Italian people through widespread depictions of aircraft in a variety of media.<ref name="W109"/> For example there was an entire branch of the [[Futurism|Futurist Art movement]] devoted to aviation, known as ''[[Aeropittura]]'' (Aeropainting).<ref name="Osborn">{{cite web |url= http://simultaneita.net/tulliocrali.html |title= Tullio Crali: the Ultimate Futurist Aeropainter (simultaneita.net) |accessdate= 2010-01-17 |last= Osborn |first= Bob |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref> While many of the ''Aeropittura'' works were devoted to flight rather than aircraft ''per se'', some did celebrate Italian aviation exploits, such as Alfredo Ambrosi's ''Il volo su Vienna'' (''The Flight over Vienna'') which depicted in Futurist style the [[Flight over Vienna|World War I exploit]] of [[Gabriele d'Annunzio]]; although the city of Vienna is shown in abstract in accordance with the aims of ''Aeropittura'' - namely to show the dynamism and excitement of flight - the [[Ansaldo SVA]] aircraft are very carefully and accurately rendered.<ref name="Osborn"/><ref>Wohl, p. 56.</ref> {{TOC right}}

A flight of US Navy AD-1s stood in for unavailable [[P-47 Thunderbolt]]s in the 1962 production ''[[The Longest Day (film)|The Longest Day]]'',<ref name="HIFA-1">[http://www.howitflies.com/Douglas-A-1-Skyraider How it Flies - Douglas A-1 Skyraider]. howitflies.com</ref> based on the [[Cornelius Ryan]] book of the same title.
The A-1 Skyraider made appearances in the 1968 ''[[The Green Berets (film)|The Green Berets]]'' film loosely based on the 1965 book by [[Robin Moore]].<ref name="HIFA-1" />
"Sandy" escort missions were depicted in the 1991 [[John Milius]] film ''[[Flight of the Intruder]]'' based on the [[Stephen Coonts]] novel of the same title.<ref name="HIFA-1" />
It was also featured as one of the many aircraft providing close air support during the First Battle of the Ia Drang Valley Campaign in Mel Gibson's 2002 film ''[[We Were Soldiers]]'',<ref name="HIFA-1" /><ref>[http://www.johnnycirucci.com/_mgxroot/page_entertainment_reviews_we_were_soldiers.html We were Soldiers]. johnnycirucci.com</ref> based on the book ''[[We Were Soldiers Onceâ¦ And Young]]'' by Lieutenant General (Ret.) [[Hal Moore]] and reporter [[Joseph L. Galloway]].
CGI-rendered US Navy Skyraiders were shown in the 2007 [[Werner Herzog]] film ''[[Rescue Dawn]]'', set during the [[Vietnam War]].<ref name="HIFA-1" />

==Avro Lancaster== [[File:Avro Lancaster B I PA474.jpg|thumb|left|[[Avro Lancaster]] ]]
[[Len Deighton]]'s novel ''[[Bomber (novel)|Bomber]]'' describes an attack by [[Royal Air Force]] [[Avro Lancaster]]s on [[Krefeld]], [[Germany]] during which a series of unplanned incidents leads to the [[carpet bombing]] of a small town nearby.<ref>''Bomber'' Len Deighton (1978) Harpercollins ISBN 0-586-04544-9</ref>
The Lancaster was central to the second half of the British film ''[[The Dam Busters (film)|The Dam Busters]]''. This film is a dramatisation of the real-life [[Operation Chastise]], which included the forming of the real-life [[RAF]] [[617 Squadron]] commanded by [[Wing Commander (rank)|Wing Commander]] [[Guy Gibson]], who was awarded the [[Victoria Cross]] (VC), and the real-life bombing of the [[Mohne]], [[Eder]] and [[Sorpe]] dams in Germany to interrupt water and [[hydro-electric]] power supplies to Nazi munitions factories.<ref name="Gilchrist">{{cite news |url=http://news.scotsman.com/uk/-A-dam-good-show.4090579.jp |title=A dam good show |last=Gilchrist |first=Jim |date=May 16, 2008 |publisher=Scotsman |accessdate=6 February 2010 |location=Edinburgh}}</ref> The film is based upon the books [[The Dam Busters (book)|The Dam Busters]] by [[Paul Brickhill]] and [[Enemy Coast Ahead]] by Guy Gibson.

The [[Avro Vulcan]] figures in [[Hank Searls|Anthony Gray]]'s 1965 novel ''The Penetrators'', in which an [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] officer attempts to demonstrate a weakness in the North American strategic defense system [[NORAD]] by launching a mock attack involving nine Vulcans and some [[Vickers Valiant]] tankers for [[inflight refuelling]].<ref name="ReferenceA">Gray 1965</ref> The Avro Vulcan is also used in the Bond film ''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]''.<ref name="Thunderball">[http://cinema.theiapolis.com/movie-2RMH/thunderball/storyline.html "Thunderball."] ''Theiapolis Cinema,'' 2008. Retrieved: 8 December 2009.</ref> In the original Bond novel, the bomber is known as the (fictional) ''Villiers Vindicator''.
Parts from two scrapped Vulcan bombers were used to make the set of the spaceship Nostromo from [[Ridley Scott]]'s 1979 film ''[[Alien (film)|Alien]]''.<ref>McIntee, David. ''Beautiful Monsters: The Unofficial and Unauthorized Guide to the Alien and Predator Films.'' Surrey, UK: Telos Publishing Ltd., 2005, pp. 10â44, 208, 251, 258â260. ISBN 1-903889-94-4.</ref>
The spaceship HMS ''Camden Lock'' in the BBC2 comedy series [[Hyperdrive (TV series)|Hyperdrive]] bears the serial number ''XH558''. The set and prop designer, model maker Andrew Glazebrook is quoted that, "Its registration number ''XH558'' is actually that of the Royal Air Force's 'Avro Vulcan' bomber and was suggested by the show's writers, Andy Riley and Kevin Cecil." This direct involvement with the Avro Vulcan and its role as a military aircraft is clearly connected to its science-fiction counterpart.<ref>[http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hyperdrive "Hyperdrive (TV series)."] ''Television Tropes & Idioms''. Retrieved: 27 October 2010.</ref>
==B-1 Lancer== The 1983 [[James Bond]] film ''[[Never Say Never Again]]'' features a [[cruise missile]] launch from a [[Rockwell B-1 Lancer]] (although a sequence in which cruise missiles are loaded onto the B-1 was filmed with a [[Concorde]] SST substituting for the B-1's undercarriage).<ref>[http://www.concordesst.com/duxford/archive/archivepics4.html "Concorde archive."] ''concordesst.com''. Retrieved: 8 October 2009.</ref>
The Transformers Decepticon named [[Windsweeper]] disguises himself as a B-1 Lancer.<ref>Bellomo, Mark. ''Transformers Identification and Price Guide'', p. 194. 2007</ref> A B-1 drops numerous bombs during the climactic battle scene in the 2009 film ''[[Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen]]''.<ref>[http://events.charlotteobserver.com/reviews/show/49667-review-transformers-revenge-of-the-fallen Movie Review: Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen]. charlotteobserver.com</ref>
==B-2 Spirit== The [[Northrop Grumman B-2 Spirit]] appeared in the film ''[[The Sum of All Fears (film)|The Sum of All Fears]]''.<ref name="Seelye">{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2002/06/10/us/when-hollywood-s-big-guns-come-right-from-the-source.html?fta=y |title=When Hollywood's Big Guns Come Right From the Source |last=Seelye |first=Katharine |date=June 10, 2002 |publisher=NY Times |accessdate=17 January 2010}}</ref>
==B-17 Flying Fortress== The [[Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress]] was the subject of the 1990 [[Warner Bros.]] film ''[[Memphis Belle (film)|Memphis Belle]]''.<ref name="Kilday">{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,318436,00.html |title=Final Mission |last=Kilday |first=Gregg |date=October 26, 1990 |publisher=Entertainment Weekly |pages=Issue #37 |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref> A leased [[Institut GÃ©ographique National]] B-17 was written off during a take off accident during filming.
The first appearance of the Flying Fortress in film was a Y1B-17 in the 1938 [[M-G-M]] production ''[[Test Pilot (film)|Test Pilot]]'', although for the crash scene a [[Douglas DC-2]] was modified to stand in for the bomber, the Army Air Corps being unwilling to risk even having a fire lit next to the scarce type for filming.<ref>Bowers, Peter M., "Fortress in the Sky", Sentry Books, Inc., Granada Hills, California, 1976, Library of Congress card number 76-17145, ISBN 0-913194-04-2, pages 236-237.</ref>
B-17Bs of the 132nd Bomb Squadron, 9th Bomb Group, [[March Field]], California ("Land of the Flying Fortress") were featured in the 1941 [[Paramount Pictures]] film ''[[I Wanted Wings]]'', based on the novel of the same title by 1st Lt. [[Beirne Lay, Jr.]]<ref name="CoastComp">{{cite web |url= http://www.coastcomp.com/av/fltline2/avmovie.htm#I |title= Military Aviation Movie List - I |accessdate= 20 May 2010 |last= Cram |first= Marshall et al |authorlink= |year= 1995}}</ref>
The self-explanatory 1942 [[Warner Bros.]] film ''[[Flying Fortress (film)|Flying Fortress]]'' showed [[Royal Air Force]] Fortress Is, singly, and in formation.<ref name="AeroVintageFF">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerovintage.com/fortress.htm |title= Flying Fortress (1942) |accessdate= 30 April 2010 |last= Aero Vintage Books |authorlink= |year= 2009 |month= September}}</ref>
B-17s appear in the 1943 [[RKO]] picture ''[[Bombardier (film)|Bombardier]]'', at [[Kirtland Field]], New Mexico.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsB">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerofiles.com/film-b.html |title= Aviation Films - B |accessdate= 8 May 2010 |last= Aerofiles |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref>
The 1943 [[Warner Bros.]] film ''[[Air Force (film)|Air Force]]'', directed by [[Howard Hawks]], used at least nine B-17B, C and D model Flying Fortresses to depict the early year of World War II, including the attack on Pearl Harbor.<ref name="AeroVintageAF">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerovintage.com/airforce.htm |title= Air Force (1943) |accessdate= 30 April 2010 |last= Aero Vintage Books |authorlink= |year= 2009 |month= November}}</ref>
In [[William Wyler]]'s 1946 film ''[[The Best Years of Our Lives]]'', B-17s are prominently featured. The primary male characters hitch a cross country ride in a B-17E Flying Fortress early in the story, and at the conclusion the scrapyard at [[Chino, California]] is shown full of disposal [[B-17]]s and [[YB-40]]s.<ref name="AeroVintageBestYrs">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerovintage.com/bestyrs.htm |title= The Best Years of Our Lives (1946) |accessdate= 30 April 2010 |last= Aero Vintage Books |authorlink= |year= 2006 |month= July}}</ref>
B-17s also figured prominently in the Oscar-winning 1949 film ''[[Twelve O'Clock High]]'' starring [[Gregory Peck]]. The film focuses on aviation leadership and the human toll in the USAAF strategy of daylight precision bombing.<ref name="12clock">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerovintage.com/12oclock.htm |title= Twelve O'Clock High (1949) |accessdate= 2010-01-11 |last= aerovintage.com |authorlink= |year= 2008 |month= June}}</ref> The U.S. Air Force cooperated in the production of the film, lending aircraft to the producers and allowing filming at [[Eglin Air Force Base]] and at Ozark Field.<ref name="TCM">{{cite web |url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title.jsp?stid=94088&category=Notes |title=Twelve O'Clock High |publisher=Turner Classic Movies |accessdate=6 February 2010}}</ref> The film featured an actual crash landing of a B-17, piloted by veteran stunt pilot [[Paul Mantz]].<ref name="Gazette">{{cite web |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yZMtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Y58FAAAAIBAJ&pg=7185,1597797&dq=famous+airplane+film&hl=en |title=Famous stunt flyer dies in film crash |date=July 9, 1965 |publisher=Montreal Gazette |page=35 |accessdate=6 February 2010}}</ref> The film led to a TV series [[Twelve O'Clock High (TV series)|of the same name]], again featuring the B-17.
The other post-war (1948) film about early 8th Air Force bomber operations, [[MGM]]'s ''[[Command Decision (film)|Command Decision]]'', with [[Clark Gable]] and [[Walter Pidgeon]], relied primarily on combat footage of Flying Fortresses, although at least one B-17F and one B-17G were utilized for ground filming in California.<ref name="CommandDec">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerovintage.com/command.htm |title= Command Decision (1948) |accessdate= 30 April 2010 |last= Aero Vintage Books |authorlink= |year= 2008 |month= June}}</ref>
A U.S. Coast Guard [[B-17 Flying Fortress|PB-1G "Dumbo"]], rescue variant of the B-17, carrying an [[A-1 lifeboat]], was shown in the 1954 film ''[[The High and the Mighty (film)|The High and the Mighty]]'', based on the [[Ernest K. Gann]] novel of the same name.<ref>Hardwick, Jack and Ed Schnepf. "A Viewer's Guide to Aviation Movies." ''The Making of the Great Aviation Films''. General Aviation Series, Volume 2, 1989, p. 66.</ref>
The love triangle 1958 [[Universal International Pictures]] film ''[[The Lady Takes a Flyer]]'' about a woman involved with two pilots who trade in war-surplus aircraft, featured at least two B-17s.<ref name="AeroVintageLady">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerovintage.com/lady.htm |title= Lady Takes a Flyer (1958) |accessdate= 30 April 2010 |last= Aero Vintage Books |authorlink= |year= 2009 |month= January}}</ref>
One ex-USAAF B-17 Flying Fortress and two ex-U.S. Navy [[B-17 Flying Fortress|PB-1W Flying Fortress]]es were retrieved from the boneyard, restored, and flown across the [[Atlantic Ocean]] for the making of the 1962 [[Columbia Pictures]] film ''[[The War Lover]]'', based on a [[John Hersey]] novel of the same title.<ref>Caiden, Martin, "Everything But The Flak", Dwell Sloan & Pierce, 1964.</ref>
A French [[Institut GÃ©ographique National|IGN]] B-17 had an accidental cameo in [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s 1964 dark cold war comedy ''[[Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb]]'', when the actual camera ship's shadow appeared on the ice pack below the matted-in [[B-52 Stratofortress]] model during Major "King" Kong's attack on Russia.<ref name="AeroVintageStrange">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerovintage.com/strangelove.htm |title= Dr. Strangelove (1964) |accessdate= 30 April 2010 |last= Aero Vintage Books |authorlink= |year= 2009 |month= October}}</ref>
A B-17G operated by [[Intermountain Airlines]], an actual [[Central Intelligence Agency]] front company, fitted with the [[Fulton surface-to-air recovery system|Fulton recovery system]], drops rescue gear to [[James Bond]] and his [[Bond girl]] in the Bahamas at the conclusion of the 1965 film ''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]''. This aircraft had actually been used by the CIA to insert and recover agents in the arctic that had checked on an abandoned Soviet ice station under [[Project COLDFEET]] in 1963.<ref name="AeroVintageThunderB">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerovintage.com/thunderball.htm |title= Thunderball (1965) |accessdate= 30 April 2010 |last= Aero Vintage Books |authorlink= |year= 2009 |month= October}}</ref>
Two DB-17P former drone-controllers and one B-17F tried to depict ''[[The 1000 Plane Raid]]'' in 1969.<ref name="AeroVintage1000">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerovintage.com/1000.htm |title= The 1000 Plane Raid (1969) |accessdate= 30 April 2010 |last= Aero Vintage Books |authorlink= |year= 2008 |month= March}}</ref> A DB-17P briefly appeared in the bio-pic ''[[MacArthur (film)|MacArthur]]'' in 1977, still wearing the same markings and paint it had for ''The 1000 Plane Raid''.<ref name="AeroVintageMac">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerovintage.com/macarthur.htm |title= MacArthur (1977) |accessdate= 30 April 2010 |last= Aero Vintage Books |authorlink= |year= 2009 |month= July}}</ref>
The B-17 figures prominently in the book ''KG 200''<ref>Gilman & Clive (1978), p. 314.</ref> by J.D. Gilman and J. Clive about the secret [[Luftwaffe]] unit [[KG 200]], which tested and flew many captured Allied aircraft.
==B-18 Bolo== [[Douglas B-18 Bolo]]s appeared in scenes for the 1941 [[Paramount Pictures]] film ''[[I Wanted Wings]]'', based on the novel of the same title by 1st Lt. [[Beirne Lay, Jr.]].<ref name="CoastComp" />
B-18 Bolos are prominently featured in the 1943 [[RKO]] picture ''[[Bombardier (film)|Bombardier]]'', filmed at [[Kirtland Field]], New Mexico.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsB" />
==B-25 Mitchell== The [[North American B-25 Mitchell]] was the focus of the second half of the 2001 film ''Pearl Harbor'', although critics complained that the bomber and its role were being depicted inaccurately.<ref name="Snow">{{cite news |url=http://www.forbes.com/2001/05/25/0525pearlharbor.html |title=Pearl Harbor: How Real Is It? |last=Snow |first=Richard |date=May 25, 2001 |publisher=American Heritage |accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref>
''[[Sole Survivor (1970 film)|The Sole Survivor]]'', a 1970 made-for-television film, based loosely on the [[Lady Be Good (aircraft)|Lady Be Good]], featured a B-25 in the Liberator role.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsS">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerofiles.com/film-s.html |title= Aviation Films - S |accessdate= 8 May 2010 |last= Aerofiles |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref>
[[The Twilight Zone (1959 TV series)|The Twilight Zone]] episode [[King Nine Will Not Return|''King Nine'' Will Not Return]] was also similarly based on Lady Be Good, and also used a B-25 in place of the B-24 Liberator.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0734584/ IMDB Twilight zone, "King Nine Will Not Return"]</ref>
The B-25 is featured in the 1961 [[Joseph Heller]] novel ''[[Catch-22]]''<ref name="Catch22">{{cite book |last=Heller |first=Joseph |title=Catch 22 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |year=1961 |page=453 |isbn=0-684-83339-5}}</ref> adapted into the 1970 [[Mike Nichols]] [[Catch-22 (film)|film]] which had 17 [[B-25 Mitchell aircraft in Catch-22 (film)|film unit]] B-25s in flying condition plus one non-flyable.<ref>Farmer, James H. "The Catch-22 Air Force." ''Air Classics'', Volume 8, No. 14, December 1972.</ref>
The B-25 also had feature roles in the films: ''[[Thirty Seconds over Tokyo]]'' (1944) (pilot Ted Lawson's account of the Doolittle Raid),<ref name="Dolan Edward F 1985">Dolan Edward F. Jr. Hollywood Goes to War. London: Bison Books, 1985. ISBN 0-86124-229-7</ref> ''[[Hanover Street (film)|Hanover Street]]'' (1979) based on a fictional B-25 unit stationed in England,<ref name="Dolan Edward F 1985"/> ''[[Forever Young (film)|Forever Young]]'' (1992), following a B-25 test pilot's story both in the past and present.<ref>Clarkson, Wensley. Mel Gibson: Man on a Mission. London: John Blake, 2004. ISBN 1-85782-537-3.</ref>
The B-25 Mitchell is used by the main characters Zack Snyder's 2011 film [[Sucker Punch (film)|Sucker Punch]] to battle a dragon.<ref>[http://www.kineda.com/sucker-punch-ft-emily-browning-vanessa-hudgens-and-jamie-chung/ Sucker Punch]</ref>
==B-26 Marauder== Six [[Martin B-26 Marauder|Martin B-26C Marauder]]s from [[MacDill Field]], Florida, portrayed Japanese bombers in the 1943 [[Howard Hawks]] film [[Air Force (film)|''Air Force'']].<ref name="rogerdarlington1">[http://www.rogerdarlington.co.uk/afilms.html#Max Aviation Films]</ref>
==B-29 Superfortress== The [[Boeing B-29 Superfortress]] has played an important role in several Hollywood films, particularly as that dubbed the [[Enola Gay]] which dropped the first atomic bomb. The Enola Gay was depicted in ''[[Above and Beyond (film)|Above and Beyond]]'' and ''[[The Beginning or the End]]''.<ref name="Lifton">{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/30/movies/film-hiroshima-films-always-a-political-fallout.html?pagewanted=1 |title=Hiroshima Films: Always a Political Fallout |last=Lifton |first=Robert |coauthors=Mitchell, Greg |date=July 30, 1995 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref> Film makers also used the only B-29 still flying in 1983 in the film ''[[The Right Stuff (film)|The Right Stuff]]'' to recreate the launch of the Bell X-1 for the first supersonic flight.<ref name="Wilford">{{cite web |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4rcMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CV4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6888,7655936&dq=movie+usaf&hl=en |title=Ingredients of 'The Right Stuff' |last=Wilford |first=John |date=October 23, 1983 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=6 February 2010}}</ref>
The B-29 also played the titular role in the 1980 Disney film ''[[The Last Flight of Noah's Ark]]''.<ref name="NoahsArk"> {{Cite web|url= http://www.dvdizzy.com/lastflight.html|title= The Last Flight of Noah's Ark - Disney DVD Review|accessdate= 22 August 2011|last= Ultimate Disney|authorlink= |year= 2004|month= August}}</ref>
The first Hollywood retelling of the 509th Composite Group's preparation for the atomic missions was ''Above and Beyond'', released by [[MGM]] in 1953, with [[Robert Taylor (actor)|Robert Taylor]] portraying Col. [[Paul Tibbetts]], and [[Jim Backus]] as Gen. [[Curtis LeMay]]. Filmed at [[Davis-Monthan Air Force Base]].<ref name="AerofilesFilmsA">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerofiles.com/film-a.html |title= Aviation Films - A |accessdate= 8 May 2010 |last= Aerofiles |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref>
==B-36 Peacemaker== The [[Convair B-36]] featured prominently in Paramount's ''[[Strategic Air Command (film)|Strategic Air Command]]'' (1955) starring [[James Stewart (actor)|James Stewart]], a World War II bomber pilot and member of the [[Air Force Reserve]], and written by [[Valentine Davies]] and [[Beirne Lay, Jr.]]. The film features many good aerial shots of B-36s and was primarily filmed at [[Carswell AFB]], Texas and in the Tampa, Florida area. One shot that was particularly difficult to shoot was where Stewart's character, a baseball player was standing on a baseball field and a B-36 flew overhead, casting a shadow over him and symbolizing his coming recall to active service.<ref name="St. Pete">{{cite web |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=v_UNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=a3oDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3905,4173501&dq=movie+usaf&hl=en |title=USAF, Paramount combine to shoot difficult scene |date=March 24, 1954 |publisher=St. Petersburg Times |accessdate=6 February 2010}}</ref> In the film this character is forced to crash land his B-36 in the Arctic.
==B-47 Stratojet ==
The [[Boeing B-47 Stratojet]] gets a secondary role in Paramount's ''[[Strategic Air Command (film)|Strategic Air Command]]'' (1955) starring James Stewart as the new jet that is nothing like the old B-36 he is used to.<ref>[http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/agency/sac.htm Global Security]</ref> The cockpit section used in filming this film is now at the [[March Field Air Museum]].<ref name="MarchCollection" />
==B-52 Stratofortress== [[File:Usaf.Boeing B-52.jpg|thumb|right|[[Boeing B-52 Stratofortress]] ]]
The 1957 [[Karl Malden]] film ''[[Bombers B-52]]'' gives a fictional account of the [[Boeing B-52 Stratofortress]]' introduction into service at [[Castle Air Force Base]].<ref name="TCMB52">{{cite web |url= http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title.jsp?stid=69323 |title= Bombers B-52 (1957) |accessdate= 30 April 2010 |last= Turner Classic Movies |authorlink= |year= 2010}}</ref>
The 1963 film [[A Gathering of Eagles]] focuses on the stresses of a B-52 wing commander at the height of the cold war. Some excellent visuals of the B-52 including a complex [[inflight refueling]] operation which nearly ends in disaster.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0057090/ A Gathering of Eagles]. IMDB</ref>
The B-52 was also a key part of [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s 1964 black comedy film ''[[Dr. Strangelove|Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb]]''<ref name="Southern">{{cite web |url= http://www.filmmakermagazine.com/fall2004/line_items/strangelove.php |title= Checkup with dr Strangelove |accessdate= 2010-01-11 |last= Southern |first= Terry |authorlink= |year= 2009}}</ref> and in ''[[A Gathering of Eagles]]''.<ref name="Time-SAC">{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,870298,00.html |title=Sick SAC |date=July 26, 1963 |publisher=Time |accessdate=15 February 2010}}</ref>
A B-52 was a focal point of the novel [[Trinity's Child]], by [[William Prochnau]], and the television film adaptation ''[[By Dawn's Early Light]]''.<ref name="Tucker">{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,317524,00.html |title=By Dawn's Early Light |last=Tucker |first=Ken |date=June 8, 1990 |publisher=Entertainment Weekly |pages=Issue #17 |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref>
==B-58 Hustler== Footage of [[Convair B-58 Hustler]]s were used as "Vindicator" bombers in the 1964 Cold War film ''[[Fail-Safe (1964 film)|Fail-Safe]]''.<ref name="coastcompfilm">[http://www.coastcomp.com/av/fltline2/avmovie.htm Military Aviation Movie List]</ref> Director [[Stanley Kubrick]] had filed a law suit alleging infringement on the storyline of his ''[[Dr. Strangelove|Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb]]'' which shared many plot elements with ''Fail Safe'' in order to delay the latter film's release until after his production came out.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ebookmall.com/ebook/72987-ebook.htm |title=Red Alert â Peter Bryant â Microsoft Reader eBook |accessdate=2006-11-27 |publisher=eBookMall, Inc.}}</ref>
==Beech 18== Hollywood pilot [[Frank Tallman]] famously flew a [[Beechcraft Model 18]] through a billboard in the 1963 chase epic ''[[It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World]]''.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsI">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerofiles.com/film-i.html |title= Aviation Films - I |accessdate= 8 May 2010 |last= Aerofiles |authorlink= |year= }}</ref>
==Bell 47== [[File:RNZAFbell47g.JPG|thumb|right|[[Bell 47]] ]]
The 1950s American television series ''[[Whirlybirds]]'' starred a pair of [[Bell 47]] helicopters. The association with ''Whirlybirds'' continues to be used in order to promote helicopters and the Bell 47 in particular.<ref name="b47ha">{{cite web |url= http://www.newwhirlybirds.com/NEW%20WHIRLYBIRDS%20HEADLINES.html |title= The New Whirlybirds |accessdate= 2010-01-17 |last= Rhodes, Joey and Rodriguez |first= Danny |authorlink= |year= 2003}}</ref> A Bell 47 was also one of the 'stars' of the Australian television series ''[[Skippy the Bush Kangaroo]]''.<ref name="ClassicOz">{{cite web |url= http://www.classicaustraliantv.com/ChopperSquad.htm |title= Classic Australian TV - Chopper Squad |accessdate= 2010-01-17 |last= Storey |first= Don |authorlink= |year= 2008}}</ref>
A Bell 47G3B-1 was used as the "[[Batcopter]]" in the 1966 ''[[Batman (1966 film)|Batman]]'' film. This airframe had previously appeared in ''[[Lassie Come Home]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalhelicopter.com/Npicture18.html |title=National Helicopter Web site with photo}}</ref>
A Bell 47 depicted an ''ersatz'' German helicopter in the 1968 action classic ''[[Where Eagles Dare]]''. Although experimental German helicopter types did exist in this time period, they were operationally used on only a limited basis and did not have performance necessary to ferry military officials as depicted in the film.<ref name="helis-1">[http://www.helis.com/timeline/bell.php "Bell Helicopters"]. Helicopter History Site.</ref><ref name="young-1">[http://www.modelaircraft.org/museum/bio/Young.pdf "Biography of ARTHUR MIDDLETON YOUNG"].</ref>
The Bell 47, in its military configuration as a [[H-13 Sioux]], was central to the television series [[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]], as well as the 1970 [[Robert Altman]] [[MASH (film)|film]] of the same name.<ref name="CSC">{{cite web |url=http://www.californiasciencecenter.org/Exhibits/AirAndSpace/AirAndAircraft/Bell47G5/Bell47G5.php |title=Air and Aircraft: Bell 47 |publisher=California Science Center |accessdate=17 January 2010}}</ref> Company clerk, Cpl. [[Radar O'Reilly|"Radar" O'Reilly]], gets his nickname from his ability to hear incoming choppers carrying wounded before anyone else.
In [[Norman Jewison]]'s 1979 film, ''[[...And Justice for All (film)|...And Justice For All]]'', a crazy judge ([[Jack Warden]]) takes a lawyer ([[Al Pacino]]) for a ride in a Bell 47G-2 that ends up ditching in [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]]'s [[Inner Harbor]] when it runs out of fuel.<ref name="RotaryactionA">[http://www.rotaryaction.com/a.html Rotary Action - A]. rotaryaction.com</ref>
==Bell 206== ''[[Chopper Squad]]'' was a 1970s Australian television series about a [[Bell 206|Bell 206 JetRanger]] used for rescue work in Sydney. The helicopter used was an actual rescue helicopter operated by the [[Westpac Life Saver Rescue Helicopter Service]].<ref name="ClassicOz"/>
A Bell 206B was one of the helicopters that attacks the oil rig control center of [[Ernst Stavro Blofeld]] in the climactic scenes of the 1971 [[James Bond]] film ''[[Diamonds Are Forever (film)|Diamonds Are Forever]]''.<ref name="rotaryaction.com">{{cite web |url= http://www.rotaryaction.com/d.html |title= Rotary Action - D |accessdate= 19 May 2010 |last= Pigasus Press |authorlink= |year= 2010}}</ref> The Jet Ranger also appeared in the Bond film ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me]]''.<ref name="rotaryactionS">{{cite web |url= http://www.rotaryaction.com/s.html |title= Rotary Action - S |accessdate= 13 August 2010 |last= Pigasus Press |authorlink= |year= 2010}}</ref>
In the film ''[[Blue Thunder]]'', a Jet Ranger plays the part of a [[Los Angeles Police Department|LAPD]] Police Helicopter for the [[LAPD Air Support Division|Astro divsion]].<ref name="Blue Thunder"/>
==Bell 222== A [[Bell 222|Bell 222A]] was featured in the television film ''[[Airwolf]]'' which starred [[Jan-Michael Vincent]] and [[Ernest Borgnine]]. Within the year, the film was made into a TV series which aired from 1984 to 1986.<ref>[http://www.rotaryaction.com/pages/airwolf.html Rotary Action - Airwolf]</ref>
In the film ''[[Harley Davidson and the Marlboro Man]]'' a [[Bell 222|Bell 222UT]] is used to eliminate the antagonists in a high rise building near downtown [[Los Angeles]].<ref name="RotaryActionSH3">{{cite web |url= http://www.rotaryaction.com/h.html |title= Rotary Action - H |accessdate= 19 May 2010 |last= Pigasus Press |authorlink= |year= 2010}}</ref>
==Bell H-1 Iroquois== [[File:UH-1D helicopters in Vietnam 1966.jpg|thumb|right|[[Bell UH-1 Iroquois]] ]]
The [[Bell UH-1 Iroquois]] (commonly called the [[Bell Huey family|Huey]]) was a central part of the 2002 film ''[[We Were Soldiers]]''. The helicopter was shown ferrying troops into the [[Battle of Ia Drang|Ia Drang]] valley as part of the then-new concept of [[air cavalry]]. The film particularly focused on the flights of Major [[Bruce Crandall]], who was later awarded the [[Medal of Honor]] for his actions while piloting his UH-1 during the battle depicted in the film.<ref name="Galloway">{{cite news |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0LIY/is_6_89/ai_n27578784/ |title=Hollywood gets Vietnam right this time |last=Galloway |first=Joseph |date=February 2002 |publisher=VFW Magazine |accessdate=17 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="Shaughnessy">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/02/26/crandall.medal.of.honor/ |title=Vietnam hero on film gets highest honor for valor |last=Shaughnessy |first=Larry |date=February 27, 2007 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=17 January 2010}}</ref> Four of the UH-1s used were provided by the [[Georgia Army National Guard]].<ref name="GADOD">{{cite web |url=http://www.dod.state.ga.us/firstfriday/march01stfriday.html |title=Georgia National Guard is in the Movies |date=March 2, 2001 |publisher=Georgia Department of Defense |accessdate=17 January 2010}}</ref>
The UH-1 was an important part of the 1968 film ''[[The Green Berets (film)|The Green Berets]]''. The production company paid $18,623.64 for the material, the eighty-five hours of flying time by UH-1 helicopters, and thirty-eight hundred man-days for military personnel taken away from their regular duties.<ref name="Smith, J.">{{cite book |last=Smith |first=Julian |title=Looking Away: Hollywood and Vietnam |publisher=Scribner |location=New York |year=1975 |edition=1st |isbn=978-0-684-13954-8 |accessdate=January 17, 2010}}</ref>
Two UH-1H Hueys make up part of the attack package on [[Ernst Stavro Blofeld]]'s oil rig command center at the climax of the 1971 [[James Bond]] film ''[[Diamonds Are Forever (film)|Diamonds Are Forever]]''.<ref name="rotaryaction.com"/>
UH-1s were prominently featured in [[Oliver Stone]]'s 1986 film [[Platoon (film)|''Platoon'']].<ref>[http://www.centennialofflight.gov/essay/Rotary/Huey/HE11.htm Bell UH-1 "Huey"]</ref>
In the 1986 film ''[[Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home]]'', [[Hikaru Sulu]] uses a Bell 204 Huey to deliver plexiglas to the Klingon ship in [[Golden Gate Park]], San Francisco.<ref name="rotaryactionS" />
The 1990 film ''[[Air America (film)|Air America]]'', about the [[CIA]]'s proprietary airline during the war in Southeast Asia, featured the ubiquitous Huey helicopter.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsA" />
The slaying of Israeli athletes by [[Black September]] terrorists and the destruction of a Bundesgrenzschutz Bell/Dornier UH-1D<ref>[http://aviation-safety.net/wikibase/wiki.php?id=75326 ASN Wikibase Occurrence # 75326]</ref> during the 1972 Summer Olympics was depicted in the 2005 [[Steven Spielberg]] film [[Munich (film)|''Munich'']].<ref Name="RotaryM">[http://www.rotaryaction.com/m.html Rotary Action M]</ref>
The UH-1 was in Francis Ford Coppola's ''[[Apocalypse Now]]''. Several Hueys were rented from the Philippine Air force.<ref name="ApocalypseNow">{{cite web |url= http://www.centennialofflight.gov/essay/Rotary/Huey/HE11.htm |title= Bell UH-1 "Huey" |accessdate= 2 July 2010 |last= U.S. Centennial of Flight Commission |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref>
==Bell X-1== The [[Bell X-1]] was depicted early in the film ''[[The Right Stuff (film)|The Right Stuff]]''. The film showed the historic flight of the X-1 becoming the first aircraft to break the sound barrier. This achievement helped usher in the U.S. space program that was the subject of the rest of the film.<ref name="Wilford">{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/16/movies/the-right-stuff-from-space-to-the-screen.html?&pagewanted=all |title=.'THE RIGHT STUFF': FROM SPACE TO THE SCREEN |last=Wilford |first=John |date=October 16, 1983 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref> Mock-up is now displayed at the [[Planes of Fame]] Museum, Chino, California.<ref name="Xplanes">[http://www.ais.org/~schnars/aero/x-planes.htm The X-Planes]</ref>
==Bell X-2== For the pilot-film of the TV-series ''[[Quantum Leap (TV series)|Quantum Leap]]'' a [[Bell X-2]] mock-up was built, which is now on display at the [[Planes of Fame]] Museum, Chino, California, together with the X-1 mock-up from the film [[The Right Stuff (film)|''The Right Stuff'']].<ref name="Xplanes" />
==Boeing 314== The [[Ken Follett]] novel ''[[Night Over Water]]'' is the story of a group of people who are travelling from England to the United States in a [[Boeing 314]] at the beginning of [[World War II]].<ref name="Follett">{{cite web |url=http://www.ken-follett.com/bibliography/night_over_water.html |title=Night Over Water - official website |accessdate= 2010-01-14 |last=Follett |first=Ken}}</ref>
==Boeing 707==
A [[Boeing 707]] leased from [[Flying Tiger Line]] portrayed two aircraft in the 1970 film ''[[Airport (1970 film)|Airport]]'', based on the 1968 [[Arthur Hailey]] [[Airport (novel)|novel of the same name]].<ref name="C707349C">{{cite web |url= http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19890321-0 |title= Accident description - Boeing 707-349C |accessdate= 8 May 2010 |last= Aviation Safety Network |authorlink= |year= 1989 |month= March}}</ref>
The Boeing 707 serves as the platform for the real-life [[E-3 Sentry]], an airborne warning and control aircraft. In the [[Tom Clancy]] novel ''"[[Debt of Honor]]"'', the E-3s operated by the U.S. were high priority targets for the air forces of Japan.<ref name="Debt of Honor">{{cite book |last=Clancy |first=Tom |title=Debt of Honor |publisher=G.P. Putnam's Sons |location=NYC |year=1994 |pages= |isbn=0-399-13954-0}}</ref>

ISBN 978-1-60585-217-1.]</ref>
==Boeing 747== [[File:Air Force One over Mt. Rushmore.jpg|thumb|right|[[Boeing VC-25]] Air Force One]]
The [[Boeing 747]] was featured in the film ''[[Executive Decision]]'' as the location of a terrorist hijacking.<ref name="Kemper">{{cite web |url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1996-09-08/features/9609060045_1_pentagon-fighter-recruitment/2 |title=The Military And the Movies |last=Kemper |first=Bob |date=September 8, 1996 |publisher=Daily Press |page=2 |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref>
A 747-146 was the title subject of the film ''[[Air Force One (film)|Air Force One]]'', portraying the real 747-200 [[Boeing VC-25|VC-25]] that transports the President of the United States.<ref name="Larson">{{cite web |url=http://www.avweb.com/news/reviews/182370-1.html |title= The Making of Air Force One |last=Larson |first=Gary |date= November 1, 1997 |publisher= Air & Space/Smithsonian |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="Times-AFO">{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/25/movies/just-a-little-turbulence-mr-president.html?pagewanted=1 |title= Just a Little Turbulence, Mr. President |last= Maslin |first= Janet |date= July 25, 1997 |publisher= NY Times |accessdate= 16 January 2010}}</ref>
The 747 was depicted several times in the best selling [[Tom Clancy]] novel ''[[Debt of Honor]]''. Most prominently, a [[Japan Airlines]] 747 was used in a suicide attack on the [[United States Capitol|U.S. Capitol building]], killing the President, most of the cabinet and the congress who were present for a [[joint session of the United States Congress]].<ref name="Debt of Honor"/> This event laid the premise for the novel ''[[Executive Orders]]'', another best seller. It was also prominent in the novel and the film ''[[The Sum of All Fears (film)|The Sum of All Fears]]'' as the [[Boeing E-4|National Airborne Operations Center]] during a nuclear showdown with Russia.<ref name="Seelye"/>
In the film ''[[Soul Plane]]'', the plane is a heavily modified 747, customized with low-rider hydraulics, spinning rims, and painted purple.<ref>[http://movies.tvguide.com/soul-plane/review/137491 Soul Plane: Review]. TVGuide.com.</ref>
In the 2010 film ''[[Inception]]'', the team flew in a 747 from Sydney to the US, and performed the inception task while aboard.<ref>Ebert, Roger. [http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100714/REVIEWS/100719997 Inception film review]. ''Chicago Sun-Times'', July 14, 2010.</ref>
A redressed [[American Airlines]] [[Boeing 747]] was featured extensively in the 1974 film ''[[Airport 1975]]''.<ref>Ortega, Sergio. [http://airodyssey.net/2005/01/01/movie-arpt75/ Airport 1975 (Movie review)]. airodyssey.net, January 1, 2005.</ref>
A 747 in-flight is also the setting for the 2006 [[horror film|horror-thriller]] film ''[[Snakes On A Plane]]'' in which a large number of venomous snakes wriggle loose on the large jet, corralled by an FBI agent played by [[Samuel L Jackson]].<ref name="SnakesOnAPlane"> {{Cite news|url= http://movies.sky.com/snakes-on-a-plane/review|title= Snakes On A Plane|accessdate= 1 September 2011|last= Evans |first= Tim |authorlink= |year= 2011|month= September |work= BSkyB}}</ref><ref name="SeattleTimes05May06"> {{Cite news|url= http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/living/2002972643_snakes05.html |title= NYDailyNews|accessdate= 14 September 2011|last= Gutierrez|first= Lisa|authorlink= |year= 2006|month= May |work= [[Seattle Times]]}}</ref><ref name="DailyNews19Aug06"> {{Cite news|url= http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/2006/08/19/2006-08-19_hiss-terical_stuff_.html|title= Hiss-terical Stuff!|accessdate= 2 September 2011|last= Matthews|first= Jack|authorlink= |year= 2006|month= August |work= [[New York Daily News]]}}</ref>
==Boeing 757== A [[Boeing 757]] was depicted in the 2006 film [[United 93 (film)|''United 93'']] recounting the story of the fourth airliner hijacked in the [[September 11 attacks]], [[United Airlines Flight 93]].<ref name="rogerdarlington1"/>
==Boeing 767== The [[Boeing E-767]], a [[Boeing 767|767]] configured as an [[airborne early warning and control]] aircraft, was central to the plot in the [[Tom Clancy]] novel ''[[Debt of Honor]]''. During a war between the U.S. and Japan, the E-767s were considered valuable assets to be protected by the operating Japanese and high priority targets for the U.S. military.<ref name="Debt of Honor">{{cite book |last=Clancy |first=Tom |title=Debt of Honor |publisher=G.P. Putnam's Sons |location=NYC |year=1994 |page=634 |isbn=0-399-13954-0}}</ref>
==Boeing-Sikorsky RAH-66 Comanche== The sole film appearance of the canceled [[Boeing-Sikorsky RAH-66 Comanche]] was in director [[Ang Lee]]'s ''[[Hulk (film)|Hulk]]'' in 2003.<ref>[http://www.rotaryaction.com/history.html Rotary Action - Notes on the history of helicopters]</ref>
