==Bugatti Model 100== In the [[Salman Rushdie]] book ''[[Shalimar the Clown]]'', the [[Bugatti Model 100]] [[Air racing|air racer]] was depicted as being completed to military model 110 standards and test flown before being hidden in a haybarn from the Germans during the invasion of France in 1940.<ref>{{cite book |title=Shalimar The Clown |author=Salman Rushdie}}</ref>
==C-47 Skytrain / Dakota== ''See also [[Aircraft_in_fiction#Douglas_DC-3|Douglas DC-3]] the civilian aircraft on which the Dakota was based.''
A ski-equipped [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain]] is featured in [[Howard Hawks]]' 1951 science-fiction thriller, ''[[The Thing From Another World]]'', based on the 1938 novella "''[[Who Goes There?]]''" by [[John W. Campbell, Jr.]].<ref>[http://www.bananalogic.net/reviews/sci-fi-sunday-the-thing-from-another-world/ Sci-Fi Sunday: The Thing From Another World!]</ref>
Eleven [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain]]s were gathered for airdrop scenes in the film ''[[A Bridge Too Far (film)|A Bridge Too Far]]'', all of which had to be of a paratroop configuration.<ref name="Hurst, Flt 1977, p. 33-34" />
==C-54 Skymaster== The [[20th Century Fox]] production ''[[The Big Lift]]'' (originally titled ''Quartered City''), set during the [[Berlin Airlift]], was filmed in Berlin at a former German studio near [[Tempelhof]] in 1949 and [[Douglas C-54 Skymaster]]s were prominently featured. Military personnel from [[Rhein-Main Air Base]] appeared as extras.<ref>Provan, John, and Davies, R. E. G., "Berlin Airlift: The Effort and the Aircraft", Paladwr Press, McLean, Virginia, ISBN 1-888962-05-4, page 64.</ref>
==C-74 Globemaster== A [[Douglas C-74 Globemaster]] appeared in the [[Michael Caine]] film ''[[The Italian Job]]''.<ref name="C74">{{cite web |url= http://cgibin.rcn.com/jeremy.k/cgi-bin/gzUsafSearch.pl?target=&content=Globemaster |title= USAF Serial Number Search Results - Description Criteria: Globemaster |accessdate= 8 May 2010 |last= cgibin.rcn.com |authorlink= |year= 2010 |month= May}}</ref>
==C-82 Packet== The crash of a [[Fairchild C-82 Packet]] in the North African desert is central to the plot of ''[[The Flight of the Phoenix (1965 film)|The Flight of the Phoenix]]'' drawn from a 1964 novel by [[Elleston Trevor]] of the same title.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsF">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerofiles.com/film-f.html |title= Aviation Films - F |accessdate= 8 May 2010 |last= Aerofiles |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref>
==C-119 Flying Boxcar== [[File:C-119(021001-O-9999G-016).jpg|thumb|right|[[Fairchild C-119 Flying Boxcar]] ]]
The [[Fairchild C-119 Flying Boxcar]] was the subject of the 2004 [[Flight of the Phoenix (2004 film)|remake of Flight of the Phoenix]], using the descendant design of the [[C-82 Packet]] of the original.<ref>[http://www.ruudleeuw.com/c119-n3267u.htm Fairchild C-119F "Boxcar" N3267U]</ref> Not well-received at the box office, the film also incorrectly depicted the C-119 engines using [[Coffman starter]] cartridges like the C-82, while the later design used a {{convert |5 |hp |kW |1 |abbr=on}} [[auxiliary power unit]] to start engines.
==C-121 Constellation== [[Lockheed C-121 Constellation|Lockheed C-121A Constellation]], ''48-615'', was used in the 1976 filming of [[MacArthur (film)|''MacArthur'']], starring [[Gregory Peck]], painted in [[Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces]] (SCAP) markings. The film was released in 1977.<ref>[http://www.joebaugher.com/usaf_serials/1946.html 1946-1948 USAAF Serial Numbers]</ref>
==C-123 Provider== The 1990 film ''[[Air America (film)|Air America]]'' loosely recounted the exploits of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] proprietary airline in Southeast Asia in the 1960s and early '70s and featured [[Fairchild C-123 Provider|Fairchild C-123K Providers]] leased from the Royal Thai Air Force.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsA" />
The C-123 was featured in the 1997 film ''[[Con Air]]'', with much of the film's action taking place in and around the aircraft.<ref>Sweetman, Bill. [http://www.airspacemag.com/how-things-work/sweetman.html?c=y&page=4 "How the 747 Got Its Hump", p. 4]. ''Air & Space magazine'', May 1, 2003.</ref>
==C-130 Hercules== A [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules]] was featured in the 1987 [[James Bond]] film ''[[The Living Daylights]]'', although a [[C-123 Provider|C-123K Provider]] was swapped out in some tail ramp fight scene close-ups.<ref name="JamesBondHercules">{{cite web |url= http://www.jamesbondmm.co.uk/vehicles/hercules |title= Hercules |accessdate= 19 May 2010 |last= James Bond MultiMedia |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref>
The special operations variant, the [[Lockheed MC-130]] Combat Talon was featured as the rescue aircraft in the film ''Air Force One'', performing a daring mid-air rescue of the President and his family as Air Force One is failing and going into the water.<ref name="Larson">{{cite web |url=http://www.avweb.com/news/reviews/182370-1.html |title=The Making of Air Force One |last=Larson |first=Gary |date=November 1, 1997 |publisher=Air & Space/Smithsonian |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref>
In the 2007 film ''[[Transformers (film)|Transformers]]'' a variant of the C-130, the [[Lockheed AC-130|AC-130 Spectre/Spooky]], is used to drive off the Decepticons when the military base in Qatar is attacked; by executing a [[pylon turn]] to deliver ground fire.<ref name="Transformers put airmen">{{cite web |url= http://www.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123059424 |title= 'Transformers' put airmen, aircraft on big screen}}</ref>
==Capelis XC-12== The oddball [[Capelis XC-12]], an unsuccessful 1933 transport design, appears as a bomber in the 1942 Republic film ''[[Flying Tigers (film)|Flying Tigers]].<ref name="FlyingTigersFilms" />
==CASA 2.111== Several ex-Spanish Air Force [[CASA 2.111]]s were used as "stand-ins" to depict German [[Heinkel He 111]] bombers in the film ''Battle of Britain''.<ref name="Warbirds directory">{{cite book |last=Chapman, John and |first=Goodall, Geoff |title=Warbirds Directory: an International Survey of the World's Warbird Population |publisher=Warbirds Worldwide |location=Mansfield, Notts |year=1992 |page=185 |isbn=}}</ref>
==Cessna 310== [[Image:Songbird III.jpg|thumb |right |Cessna 310D Songbird III used in later episodes of [[Sky King]]]] The [[Cessna 310|Cessna 310B]], "Songbird", registration N5348A, was featured in many episodes of the popular TV show ''[[Sky King]]'' during the late 1950s.<ref name="IMDB">{{cite web |url= http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0043232/ |title= Sky King |accessdate= 2009-08-29 |last= Internet Movie Database |authorlink= |year= 2009}}</ref>
==CG-4 Haig / Hadrian== Crashed [[Waco CG-4|WACO CG-4A]] gliders of the [[99th Airlift Squadron|99th Troop Carrier Squadron]] were depicted by replicas in the film ''[[Saving Private Ryan]]''. These were recreated using measurements taken from a surviving example at the [[Museum of Army Flying]], Middle Wallop, [[Hampshire, England]].<ref>[http://www.sproe.com/g/glider.html CG-4A Haig Glider]</ref>
==CH-34 Choctaw / Westland Wessex== [[Westland Wessex]] helicopters portrayed [[CH-34 Choctaw]]s in [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s ''[[Full Metal Jacket]]''.<ref name="rose">{{cite news |last= Rose |first= Lloyd |coauthors= |title= Stanley Kubrick, At a Distance |work= |pages= |language= |publisher= Washington Post |date= June 28, 1987 |url= http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/movies/features/kubrick1987.htm |accessdate= 2007-10-11 }}</ref>
Turbine-repowered [[Sikorsky S-58]]Ts portrayed [[CH-34 Choctaw]]s in the 1990 film ''[[Air America (film)|Air America]]'' about the exploits of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] proprietary airline during the war in Southeast Asia.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsA" />
==CH-46 Sea Knight / Boeing-Vertol 107== A Kawasaki-built KV-107 portrays a [[Boeing Vertol CH-46 Sea Knight]] that airlifts a team of hijackers aboard the [[USS Missouri (BB-63)|USS ''Missouri'']] in the 1992 film ''[[Under Siege]]'', and is depicted being blown up on the fantail of the battleship later in the film.<ref name="rotaryactionU">{{cite web |url= http://www.rotaryaction.com/u.html |title= Rotary Action - U |accessdate= 13 August 2010 |last= Pigasus Press |authorlink= |year= 2010}}</ref>
In the film ''[[You Only Live Twice (film)|You Only Live Twice]]'' a [[Boeing Vertol CH-46 Sea Knight|Kawasaki-built KV-107]] has a electromagnet slung loaded underneath, and uses it to airlift an antagonists car off the road, thereby freeing up [[James Bond]] from their pursuit.<ref>[http://www.rotaryaction.com/y.html Rotary Action - Y]</ref>
==Concorde== [[File:Concorde on Bristol.jpg|right|thumb|[[Concorde]] ]]
[[Concorde]] was a central feature in the [[disaster film]] ''[[The Concorde ... Airport '79]]''. A French Concorde was leased from the manufacturers for filming.<ref name="f-btsc">{{cite web |url=http://www.concordesst.com/accident/203a.html |title=Concorde Accident |publisher=Awww.concordesst.com |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref> The aircraft used was the aircraft which [[Air France Flight 4590|crashed in 2000]].
The Transformers character [[Silverbolt]] turns into a Concorde.<ref name="Schroeders">[http://books.google.com/books?cd=2&id=GXKFR1S1OJsC&dq=aerialbot&q=skydive Schroeder's Collectible Toys: Antique to Modern Guide By Sharon Huxford, Bob Huxford]</ref>
In the [[Doctor Who]] serial "[[Time-Flight]]", Concorde, its passengers and crew are pulled through time to a prehistoric version of Earth.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/episodeguide/timeflight/detail.shtml Time Flight details]. BBC. Retrieved: 15 April 2010.</ref>
==Consolidated NY== U.S. Navy [[Consolidated NY]] trainers from [[Floyd Bennett Field]] appeared as some of the biplanes that attack ''[[King Kong]]'' atop the [[Empire State Building]] in the 1933 original film.<ref name="tcm.com">{{cite web |url= http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title.jsp?stid=2690&category=Notes |title= Notes for King Kong (1933) |accessdate= 19 May 2010 |last= Turner Classic Movies |authorlink= |year= 2010}}</ref>
==Curtiss RC-1== The rare U.S. Marine Corps [[Curtiss Kingbird|Curtiss RC-1]] air ambulance, ''A-8864'', made an appearance in the 1935 [[Warner Bros.]] film "''[[Devil Dogs of the Air]]''" starring [[James Cagney]] and [[Pat O'Brien (actor)|Pat O'Brien]].<ref>[http://aerofiles.com/_curtx.html Aerofiles Curtiss K through Z]</ref>
==Dassault Mirage 2000== The [[Dassault Mirage 2000]]-5 featured prominently in the 2005 French film ''Les Chevaliers du Ciel'' (''The Knights of the Sky'' in literal translation, released as ''Sky Fighters'' in English-speaking territories).<ref name="Les Chevaliers du Ciel">{{cite web |url= http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0421974/ |title= Les chevaliers du ciel (2005) |accessdate= 2010-02-22 |last= IMDB |authorlink= |year= 2010}}</ref>
The Transformers character [[Needlenose]] disguises itself as a Dassault Mirage 2000.<ref>Transformers Identification and Price Guide by Mark Bellomo, 2007, p. 196</ref>
==de Havilland Canada DHC-2 Beaver== The [[de Havilland Canada DHC-2 Beaver]] was central to the film ''[[Six Days Seven Nights]]''. The actual flying in the film was done by its star, [[Harrison Ford]], who enjoyed flying the Beaver so much that he bought one after filming was completed.<ref name="Hunt-Grand">{{cite web |url=http://www.grandmagazine.com/article.asp?id=112 |title=The Passions of Harrison Ford |last=Hunt |first=Mary |date=FEBRUARY/MARCH 2005 |publisher=Grand Magazine |pages=34â36 |accessdate=5 February 2010}}</ref> Three flying Beavers and four non-flyable were used in the production, all detailed to exactly match one another.<ref>[http://www.studiowings.com/testm_flyingmag.html The making of "Six Days / Seven Nights" Flying - June, 1998]</ref>
The 1982 film ''[[Mother Lode (film)|Mother Lode]]'' made use of a Canadian-registered former [[US Army]] DHC-2 Beaver on floats as the neglected mount of character Jean DuprÃ© ([[Nick Mancuso]]), who embarks on a search for a missing friend in northern [[British Columbia]]. During the filming the aircraft actually crashed while landing on a lake and sunk. This accident was not in the original script, but the footage was retained and incorporated into the film's plot. The aircraft was recovered from the lake, repaired, restored and exported to the US.<ref>[http://www.dhc-2.com/id181.htm DHC-2 Beaver registration database of known surviving aircraft.]</ref>
==de Havilland Comet== The [[de Havilland Comet]] airliner is featured in the 1952 British film ''[[The Sound Barrier]]''.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsB" />
==de Havilland DH.4== The 1927 [[William Wellman]] film [[Wings (film)|''Wings'']] featured [[Airco DH.4|de Havilland DH.4]]s amongst many types depicting [[World War I]] aircraft.<ref name="historynet1">[http://www.historynet.com/top-10-best-and-worst-aviation-movies.htm/2 Boyne, Walter J., Top 10 Best and Worst Aviation Movies]</ref>
==de Havilland Fox Moth== [[File:DH.83C Fox Moth G-AOJH N.West AS RWY 06.58 edited-2.jpg|thumb|right|[[de Havilland Fox Moth]] ]]
The novel ''[[Round the Bend (1951 novel)|Round the Bend]]'' by [[Nevil Shute]] is the story of two men, both British [[Aircraft Maintenance Engineer|Licenced Aircraft Engineers]]. A large number of different aircraft types, both fictitious and real, feature in the book. The narrator and one of the protagonists of the story is Tom Cutter, and the novel details his efforts to establish an [[air charter]] business in [[Bahrain]] immediately after World War II. His first aircraft is a [[de Havilland Fox Moth]]; it is later joined by several other aircraft as the business expands, mostly fictitious, but among them a [[Percival Proctor]].<ref name="Round the Bend"/>
==de Havilland Hornet Moth== The novel ''[[Hornet Flight]]'' by Ken Follett is a thriller of [[Danish resistance movement|the Resistance against the Nazi occupation of Denmark]] in World War II. In the novel a [[de Havilland Hornet Moth]] is used by the protagonists to fly from Denmark to the United Kingdom with information about a German radar system. The author drew inspiration from an actual flight that took place during World War II.<ref name="Follett2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ken-follett.com/bibliography/hornet_flight.html |title=Hornet Flight - official website |accessdate= 2010-01-14 |last=Follett |first=Ken}}</ref>
==de Havilland Mosquito== In the 1954 British film ''[[The Purple Plain]]'' with [[Gregory Peck]], a Canadian pilot during WWII crashes a [[de Havilland Mosquito]] on the Burma plain and struggles to survive.<ref>Military Aviation Movie List: [http://www.coastcomp.com/av/fltline2/avmovie.htm The Purple Plain]</ref>
[[de Havilland Mosquito]]s feature prominently in the 1964 film ''[[633 Squadron]]'' alongside actors [[Cliff Robertson]] and [[Harry Andrews]]. The film was notable for its use of genuine, airworthy aircraft, rather than models, for many of the scenes.<ref>O'Hara, Bob. "633 Squadron." The Making of the Great Aviation Films, Volume 2, 1989.</ref>
Mosquitos also play the title role of the 1969 film ''[[Mosquito Squadron]]'', starring [[David McCallum]] and [[Charles Gray (actor)|Charles Gray]].<ref>[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1968/1968%20-%201345.html Letter to ''Flight'' (1968)]. Flight</ref>
The Mosquito plays an important role with the [[de Havilland Vampire]] in [[Frederick Forsyth]]'s novella ''[[The Shepherd]]''.<ref name="Sheperd">{{cite web |url= http://www.aircraftresourcecenter.com/Gal8/7001-7100/gal7022-Santa-Shepherd-Petrie/00.shtm |title= "The Shepherd" Story by Frederick Forsyth |last= Alvis 3.1 |authorlink= |year= |accessdate= 31 December 2010}}</ref>
Mosquitos are featured prominently in the [[The Adventures of Tintin|Tintin]] comic book album [[The Red Sea Sharks]]. They drive the plot in various ways, first as war-surplus equipment offered for sale by an [[arms dealer]] early in the story, and later in combat.<ref name="RedSeaSharks">{{cite web |url= http://www.ciao.co.uk/The_Red_Sea_Sharks_Herge__Review_5421434 |title= A Cargo of Coke |accessdate= 17 March 2010 |last= Worrals |year= 2004 |month= August}}</ref>
[[Cyclops (comics)|Scott Summers]] and his younger brother [[Havok (comics)|Alex Summers]], members of [[Marvel Comics]]'s [[X-Men]], are orphaned as children after parachuting out of their father's [[de Havilland Mosquito]] when it is set ablaze by an alien attack.<ref>''X-Factor'' vol. 1 #39</ref>
==de Havilland Vampire== The [[de Havilland Vampire]] was central to the plot of the novella, ''[[The Shepherd]]'' by British novelist [[Frederick Forsyth]], the story of an RAF pilot attempting to fly home for [[Christmas]] from [[RAF Celle]], [[Germany]] to [[RAF Lakenheath]] on [[Christmas Eve]] 1957. The fact that the DH.100 was not fitted with [[ejection seat]]s until about 10 years later, and hence was a major challenge to bail out of, is an important element of the story.<ref>[http://www.lovereading.co.uk/book/9780099642510/isbn/The-Shepherd-by-Frederick-Forsyth.html "Book Review: The Shepherd by Frederick Forsyth."] ''lovereading.co.uk'', 2009. Retrieved: 19 October 2009.</ref>
Vampire jets also feature in the 1966 novel ''Shooting Script'' by former RAF pilot and thriller writer [[Gavin Lyall]].<ref>Smith, Miles A. [http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19660505&id=yXIQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UYsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3958,3511572 "Book review: Whiz-bang Foreign Adventure."] ''The Free-Lance-Star'', 6 May 1966. Retrieved: 19 October 2009.</ref>
A [[French Air Force]] Vampire appears in the 1954 French-language comic ''La grande menace'' by [[Jacques Martin (comics)|Jacques Martin]], the first featuring investigative journalist Guy Lefranc; it was destroyed while engaging an unidentified helicopter.<ref>Leduc, Fabrice. [http://translate.google.ca/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://www.yozone.fr/spip.php%3Farticle3662&ei=jljcSubEH8iM8Aabipi3BQ&sa=X&oi=translate&resnum=4&ct=result&ved=0CBsQ7gEwAw&prev=/search%3Fq%3D%2527%2527La%2Bgrande%2Bmenace%2527%2527%2BJacques%2BMartin%2B1954%26hl%3Den "Martin Jacques: The greatest threat."] ''yozone.fr''. Retrieved: 19 October 2009.</ref>
==Douglas DC-3== ''See also [[Aircraft_in_fiction#C-47_Skytrain_.2F_Dakota|C-47 Skytrain / Dakota]] the military version of the DC-3''
The chief character of the book ''[[High Citadel]]'' by [[Desmond Bagley]] is an alcoholic former Korean War fighter pilot who flies a [[Douglas DC-3]] for a small airline in a fictional Andean country in South America. He is forced at gunpoint by his co-pilotâa Communist agentâto crash-land the DC-3 at a remote abandoned mine in the Andes so that Communists planning a coup can capture and kill a politician travelling as a passenger.<ref name="BagCit"/>
An episode of ''[[The Twilight Zone]]'' entitled [[The Arrival (The Twilight Zone)|"The Arrival"]] features a [[Douglas DC-3]] known as Flight 107, which arrives at its destination with no one onboard. It originally aired 22 September 1961.<ref name="Zicree">Zicree, Marc Scott: ''The Twilight Zone Companion''. Sillman-James Press, 1982 (second edition)</ref>
In the 1989 comedy film ''[[Major League (film)|Major League]]'', the hard-luck [[Cleveland Indians]] baseball team is "upgraded" to a DC-3 for their transportation to away games.<ref>[http://www.imsdb.com/scripts/Major-League.html "Major League" Screenplay by David S. Ward, Shooting Draft]</ref>
==Douglas DC-4== [[File:C-54landingattemplehof.jpg|right|thumb|[[Douglas C-54 Skymaster]] ]]
A former USAF [[Douglas C-54 Skymaster]] operated by [[Transocean Airlines]] portrayed the [[Douglas DC-4]] in the 1954 film ''[[The High and the Mighty (film)|The High and the Mighty]]'' based on the [[Ernest K. Gann]] novel of the same name.<ref>Shane, Bob. "The Makings of 'The High and the Mighty': A Former Airline Pilot Remembers the Filming of an Aviation Classic." Airpower, Volume 36, no. 1, January 2006.</ref> Ironically, this airframe was lost over the Pacific on 28 March 1964 with an engine fire just as depicted in the film. There were no survivors of the nine "souls on board" and the wreckage was never found.<ref name="ASN1964">{{cite web |url= http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19640328-0 |title= Accident description - Douglas C-54A-10-DC |accessdate= 30 April 2010 |last= Aviation Safety Network |authorlink= |year= 1964 |month= March}}</ref>
==Douglas DC-7== The final scenes in the 1973 [[George Lucas]] film ''[[American Graffiti]]'' feature a [[Douglas DC-7]]C airliner of Magic Carpet Airlines which had previously been leased from owner Club America Incorporated by the rock band [[Grand Funk Railroad]] from March 1971 to June 1971.<ref>[http://www.air-and-space.com/Douglas%20DC-6%20and%20DC-7%20Tankers.htm Douglas DC-6 and DC-7 Tankers]</ref><ref>[http://www.americangraffiti.net/movie_locations.html American Graffiti Filming Locations (June - August, 1972)]</ref>
==EB-66 Destroyer== The film ''[[Bat*21]]'' featured an EB-66 variant of the [[Douglas B-66 Destroyer]]<ref name="Dean">{{cite web |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZZUpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=N6cEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3170,3798432&dq=bat-21&hl=en |title=Tale of an aging warrior's valor in Vietnam |last=Dean |first=Paul |date=November 15, 1980 |publisher=LA Times |accessdate=14 February 2010}}</ref> being shot down over North Vietnam in the beginning of the film. The rest film depicted the real life events surrounding the rescue of LTC [[Iceal Hambleton]], who was the only survivor of the 6 man crew.
==Eurocopter Tiger== A [[Eurocopter Tiger|Eurocopter EC 665 Tiger]] attack helicopter had a starring role in the 1995 [[James Bond]] film ''[[GoldenEye]]''.<ref name="Flightglobal Web Site">{{cite web |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/landingpage/eurocopter%20tiger.html |title=Flightglobal.Com - Eurocopter Tiger}}</ref> On the 2002 Special Edition DVD, the director's commentary notes the aircraft's appearances in the film's Monte Carlo scenes were of a prototype Tiger provided by the French Navy along with its test platform, the [[La Fayette (F710)|FS ''La Fayette'']]. Its other appearances throughout the rest of the film were special effects models.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113189/dvd#B00000K0E5Martin Campbell Director's Commentary soundtrack Golden Eye Special Edition DVD 2002]</ref>
==F2H Banshee== Protagonist Lt. Harry Brubaker flew a [[McDonnell F2H Banshee]] in the 1953 [[James A. Michener]] novel ''[[The Bridges at Toko-Ri (novel)|The Bridges at Toko-Ri]]''. In the subsequent 1954 [[The Bridges at Toko-Ri|film adaptation]], his aircraft was changed to a [[Grumman F9F Panther]].<ref name="flight_deck">Mersky, Peter B. (Ed.) ''From the flight deck: an anthology of the best writing on carrier warfare''. Dulles, Virginia: Brassey's, Inc., 2003. ISBN 1-57488-433-6, p. 159.</ref>
==F3F== ''[[Flight Command]]'', released by [[MGM]] in 1940, featured the [[Grumman F3F]], filmed at [[NAS North Island]], San Diego, California. Aerial flying by Frank Clarke and [[Paul Mantz]].<ref name="AerofilesFilmsF" />
The 1941 [[Warner Bros.]] film ''[[Dive Bomber (film)|Dive Bomber]]'' showed Grumman F3Fs.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsD">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerofiles.com/film-d.html |title= Aviation Films - D |accessdate= 8 May 2010 |last= Aerofiles |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref>
==F-4 Phantom II== The Gobots character Mach 3 and the Transformers character Fireflight both turn into [[McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II]]s.<ref name="Schroeders" />
[[United States Marine Corps|Marine]] aviator Lt. Col. Wilbur "Bull" Meecham flew an F-4 Phantom II in the 1976 [[Pat Conroy]] novel ''[[The Great Santini (novel)|The Great Santini]]'' and the subsequent 1979 [[The Great Santini|film adaptation]] starring [[Robert Duvall]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.oo-rah.com/store/seastories/ss33.asp |title= The Great Santini at MCAS Beaufort |last=Scoggins |first=Frank |accessdate=5 May 2011}}</ref>
In book "World War Z: An Oral History of the Zombie War" by Max Brooks, an Iranian Air Force Major recalls using an F-4 Phantom II to destroy a bridge in Pakistan, leading to a full nuclear exchange between Iran and Pakistan.<ref name=WWZ>{{cite book |last=Brooks |first=Max |title=World War Z: An Oral History of the Zombie War |year=2006 |publisher=Random House |isbn=0307346609 |pages=91}}</ref>
The F-4D Phantom II operated by the Collings Foundation will appear in the ''Green Lantern'' film, to be released in June 2011.<ref name="CollingsWinter11" />
==F4F Wildcat== [[Grumman F4F Wildcat]]s were shown in the critical aerial battle scenes in the film ''[[Midway (film)|Midway]]''.<ref name="Kleiner">{{cite web |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pDAcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rlkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2296,2553595&dq=aircraft+in+movies&hl=en |title=Making War for Movies |last=Kleiner |first=Dick |date=October 6, 1975 |publisher=Pittsburgh Press |accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref>
==F4U Corsair== The [[Vought F4U Corsair|Chance Vought F4U Corsair]] was a regularly featured aircraft of [[VMF-214]] in the television series [[Baa Baa Black Sheep (TV series)|''Baa Baa Black Sheep'']] (later renamed Black Sheep Squadron).<ref name="Osceloa News-Gazette">{{cite web |url=http://oscnewsgazette.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=5398&Itemid=9 |title=Warbird part of air museum exhibit |date=January 7, 2010 |publisher=Osceola News Gazette |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref>
==F-5 Freedom Fighter== The [[Northrop F-5|Northrop F-5 Freedom Fighter]] played the part of the fictional MiG-28 enemy aircraft in ''Top Gun''.<ref name="Lamar"/><ref name=Lindsey_Top_Gun>{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1986/05/27/movies/top-gun-ingenious-dogfights.html?&pagewanted=all |title='TOP GUN:' INGENIOUS DOGFIGHTS |last=Lindsey |first=Robert |date=May 27, 1986 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref>
==F9F Panther== [[File:XF9F-3 XF9F-2 NAN12-48.jpg|right|thumb|[[Grumman F9F Panther]]s]]
The [[Grumman F9F Panther|Grumman F9F-2 Panther]] was prominently featured in the 1954 films ''[[Men of the Fighting Lady]]'' and ''[[The Bridges at Toko-Ri]]'', although the protagonist instead flew a [[McDonnell F2H Banshee]] in the 1953 [[The Bridges at Toko-Ri (novel)|novel of the same name]] upon which the latter film was based.<ref name="flight_deck"/> Footage of the famous non-fatal [[F9F Panther|F9F-5 Panther]] [[ramp strike]] accident that occurred 23 June 1951 as Cdr. George Chamberlain Duncan attempted a landing aboard [[USS Midway (CV-41)|USS ''Midway'']] in BuNo ''125228'', during carrier suitability tests in the Atlantic Ocean in which the forward fuselage broke away and rolled down the deck, pilot suffering burns, has been used in several films including ''[[Men of the Fighting Lady]]'', ''[[Midway (film)|Midway]]'', and ''[[The Hunt For Red October]]''.<ref>[http://www.check-six.com/Crash_Sites/F9F-Duncan.htm Duncan's F9F]. Check-six.com. Retrieved on 2010-11-25.</ref>
==F11F Tiger== A heat-seeking missile launched by a [[Grumman F11F Tiger]] that accidentally strikes the port area of [[Latakia]], [[Syria]], setting off secondary explosions, gives the Soviet Union the [[casus belli]] for preemptive nuclear strikes against the United States in "[[Alas, Babylon]]", the [[post-apocalyptic]] 1959 novel by [[Pat Frank]].<ref>Frank, Pat, "Alas, Babylon", J. B. Lippincott, Philadelphia, 1959; Bantam paperback, Bantam Books, New York, 1979, ISBN 0-553-13260-1.</ref>
==F-14 Tomcat== The [[Grumman F-14 Tomcat]] was central to the film ''[[Top Gun]]''.<ref name="Air and Space"/><ref name="AP-Tomcat">{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14958926 |title=Navy retires F-14 âTop Gunâ jet |date=September 22, 2006 |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="Shaer">{{cite web |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Innovation/Horizons/2009/0721/inside-the-news-the-f-22-raptor-warplane |title=Inside the news: The F-22 Raptor warplane |last=Shaer |first=Matthew |date=July 21, 2009 |publisher=Christian Science Monitor |accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref> The aviation-themed film was such a success in creating interest in naval aviation that the U.S. Navy, who assisted with the film, set up recruitment desks outside some theaters.<ref name="Vartabedian">{{cite web |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HW4pAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9OkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6799,2509554&dq=military+hollywood&hl=en |title=The Pentagon is a big help for the right military film |last=Vartabedian |first=Ralph |date=September 10, 1986 |publisher=LA Times |accessdate=17 January 2010}}</ref> Producers paid the U.S. Navy $886,000 as reimbursement for flight time of aircraft in the film. An hour of flight time for the F-14 was billed at $7,600.<ref name="Halloran"/><ref name=Lindsey_Top_Gun/>
Two F-14As of [[VF-84]] from the [[USS Nimitz|USS ''Nimitz'']] appeared in the 1980 film ''[[The Final Countdown (film)|The Final Countdown]]'',<ref>[http://www.almansur.com/jollyrogers/jollytomcats.htm The Infamous Tomcats of VF-84]</ref> with four from the squadron in the 1996 release ''[[Executive Decision]]'',<ref name="Kemper"/> the Jolly Rogers' final film appearance before being disestablished. The television series ''[[JAG (TV series)|JAG]],'' which debuted in 1995 featured a Tomcat pilot-turned-lawyer,<ref name="Air and Space"/> and the Tomcat was a central part of the [[Stephen Coonts]] novel ''Final Flight''.<ref name="Air and Space"/>
==F-15 Eagle== The [[McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle]] is one of the most recognized modern fighters; this has led to, or perhaps even been aided by, its common use in children's toys. The Transformers toy line and media has featured numerous characters who turn into F-15 Eagles, the most notable being the villain [[Starscream (Transformers)|Starscream]] in 1984<ref name="Time30Jul01">{{cite news |url =http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1000438,00.html |title= Action Figures From The '80s |accessdate= 2009-12-09 |last= Briese |first= Beau |authorlink= |year= 2001 |month= July |work=Time}}</ref> and a group of similar Decepticons, the [[Seekers (Transformers)|Seekers]] [[Acid Storm]], [[Thundercracker]], [[Skywarp]] and [[Sunstorm (Transformers)|Sunstorm]]. Although completely unrelated design to the others, the [[Autobot]] Air Raid also disguises himself as an F-15.<ref>Transformers Identification and Price Guide by Mark Bellomo, 2007, p. 85</ref>
The F-15 is featured in the film ''[[Air Force One (film)|Air Force One]]''.<ref name="Times-AFO" /> The Eagle was also shown in advertisements for the film [[Thirteen Days (film)|''Thirteen Days'']]. The ads were withdrawn when it came to the attention of New Line Cinema that the F-15, which first flew in 1972, was out of place for a movie set in 1962. This was problematic for New Line, who had termed the film a "by-the-numbers recreation" and "close to perfect." "Every ship, plane, truck and craft that moves in the film is absolutely authentic to the time period," said Steve Elzer, a spokesman for New Line. Mr. Elzer said the advertisement was created by an outside agency.<ref name="Times-Eagle">{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2001/01/13/us/ads-for-missile-crisis-movie-are-pulled-because-of-errors.html |title=Ads for Missile-Crisis Movie Are Pulled Because of Errors |date=January 13, 2001 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref>
Air battles between F-15s were depicted in the novel ''[[Debt of Honor]]''. The battles were not only significant to the plot, but unusual in that both sides were operating the same aircraft against each other.<ref name="Debt of Honor"/>
[[Leader-1]] of the [[Gobots]] turns into an F-15.<ref>{{Cite journal |author= |title= YS Preview: Challenge of the Gobots - Come in, Leader-1 |journal= Your Sinclair |volume= 1 |issue= 20 |page= 20 |date= |url=http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=YourSinclair/Issue20/Pages/YourSinclair2000020.jpg}}</ref>
==F-16 Fighting Falcon== [[File:F-16 Fighting Falcons above New York City(2).jpg|thumb|F-16s of the USAF's ''[[United States Air Force Thunderbirds|Thunderbirds]]'' display team]]
The [[F-16 Fighting Falcon]] was featured in the film ''[[The Sum of All Fears (film)|The Sum of All Fears]]''.<ref name="Seelye"/> The Falcon was also one of the stars of the film ''[[Iron Eagle]]''. The U.S. Air Force refused to assist with production of the film because it found the plot about a teenager flying an F-16 into a foreign country to be "a little off the wall".<ref name="Halloran"/>
The Transformers Aerialbot Skydive and Decepticon [[Dreadwind]] disguise themselves as F-16s.<ref>Mark Bellomo. ''Transformers Identification and Price Guide'', 2007, pp. 87, 199.</ref>
==F/A-18 Hornet== The [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet]] appeared briefly in the film ''[[Tears of the Sun]]'' in the final, climactic battle, helping to save the surviving SEAL team members.<ref name="Mercury">{{cite web |url=http://www.lasvegasmercury.com/2003/MERC-Mar-06-Thu-2003/20806823.html |title=Willis in good action hero form with Tears of the Sun |date=March 6, 2003 |publisher=Las Vegas Mercury |accessdate=17 January 2010}}</ref>
The F/A-18 Hornet appears in the film ''[[Clear and Present Danger (film)|Clear and Present Danger]]'', where it drops a laser guided bomb on a car at a drug lord's villa, being laser designated by a special forces team.<ref name="BoeingF-18">[http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/military/fa18/fa1820/movie.htm F/A-18 Hornet Twentieth Anniversary of First Flight - On the Big Screen]. boeing.com</ref>
The F/A-18 also appears in the 1996 film ''[[Independence Day (film)|Independence Day]]'' in the hands of USMC pilots fighting aliens.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116629/synopsis Synopsis for Independence Day (1996)]</ref>
The [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet|F/A-18F Super Hornet]], a two-seat variant, was featured in the film ''[[Behind Enemy Lines (2001 film)|Behind Enemy Lines]]''. The movie centers around a Super Hornet being shot down over [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]].<ref name="Tatara">{{cite news |url=http://archives.cnn.com/2001/SHOWBIZ/Movies/11/29/review.enemy.lines/index.html |title='Enemy Lines' slam-bang silliness |last=Tatara |first=Paul |date=November 29, 2001 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=7 February 2010}}</ref>
F/A-18s attack the famous Japanese monster [[Godzilla]] (ã´ã¸ã© |Gojira) in the 1998 remake ''[[Godzilla (1998 film)|Godzilla]]''.<ref name="BoeingF-18" />
F/A-18s in the film ''[[The Rock (film)|The Rock]]'' attack the prison on [[Alcatraz Island]] in the final scenes.<ref name="CNET28Jul04">{{Cite news |url= http://reviews.cnet.com/pc-games/f-a-18-precision/1707-9696_7-30983739.html |title= F/A-18 Precision Strike Fighter (PC) |accessdate= 14 June 2011 |last= CBS Interactive |authorlink= |year= 2004 |month= July |work= CNET}}</ref>
==F-22 Raptor== The [[Lockheed Martin F-22 Raptor]] has been featured in numerous books, such as [[Tom Clancy]]'s ''[[Debt of Honor]]'' in which a lengthy mission by F-22s dominates the last part of the book;<ref name="Debt of Honor"/> and [[Clive Cussler]]'s ''[[Dark Watch]]''.<ref>Cussler, Clive. ''Dark Watch''. New York: Berkley Books, 2005. ISBN 0-425-20559-2</ref> In Cussler's book, an F-22 embarks on a secret mission to take out a Syrian foe. In ''Debt of Honor'', the F-22 (named the ''Rapier'') represented the newest in [[stealth technology]] being used by the United States against Japan's advanced [[Boeing E-767]] AWACS aircraft.<ref name="Debt of Honor"/>
The Raptor has appeared in films as well. Despite appearing in the 2003 ''[[Hulk (film)|Hulk]]'' film, the F-22 made its major Hollywood debut in the 2007 film ''[[Transformers (film)|Transformers]]'' and its [[Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen|sequel]]<ref name="Miles">Miles, Donna. [http://www.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123056463 "Movie makers team with military to create realism."] ''American Forces Press Service'', 21 June 2007. Retrieved: 23 November 2008.</ref> as the form taken by the [[Decepticon#2007 film|Decepticon]] character [[Starscream (other incarnations)#2007 Transformers film|Starscream]] in addition to numerous USAF fighters that engaged during the initial and climactic battles. The film crew was allowed to film actual Raptors in flight, unlike previous [[computer-generated]] appearances, because of the military's support of director [[Michael Bay]]. The Raptors were filmed at Edwards Air Force Base.<ref>Michael Bay's DVD audio commentary for ''Transformers'', 2007, Paramount/DreamWorks.</ref> The real Raptor made its next big screen appearance in ''[[Iron Man (film)|Iron Man]]'', in which a Raptor dubbed "Whiplash 1" lost its left wing during a crash with the Iron Man armor.<ref name="Crave">{{cite web |url=http://www.craveonline.com/entertainmentfilm/article/the-f22-raptor-heads-to-the-screen-65267 |title=The F22 Raptor heads to the screen |date=September 25, 2007 |publisher=Crave Online |accessdate=17 January 2010}}</ref>
Toys released for Starscream were replica F-22 Raptor models. These models were reused for other characters in the line, like [[Thundercracker]], [[Skywarp]] and [[Ramjet (Transformers)|Ramjet]], that also turned into F-22 Raptors.<ref name="HasbroInst2007">{{cite web |url= http://www.hasbro.com/common/instruct/83757.pdf |title= Claw Slash Ramjet |accessdate= 2009-12-09 |last= [[Hasbro]] |authorlink= |year= 2007}}</ref>
Although the live-action 2007 Transformers film made Starscream the most well known Transformer that turns into an F-22, there were other F-22 Transformers before it. For instance the 1997 ''[[Machine Wars]]'' versions of [[Megatron (Transformers)|Megatron]] and Megaplex transformed into F-22s.<ref name="MachineWarsVandom">{{cite web |url= http://www.eyrie.org/~dvandom/BW/MW/index.html |title= Transformers Machine Wars |accessdate= 2010-01-04 |last= Vandom |first= D |authorlink= |year= 1997 |month= April}}</ref>
==F-35 Lightning II== [[File:F35A Prototyp AA1 3.jpg|thumb|right|[[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II]] ]]
The first major film appearance of a representation of a [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II]] was in ''[[Live Free or Die Hard]]'' (released as ''Die Hard 4'' outside North America) in 2007. The film used a combination of a full-scale model and [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]]<ref>Gray, Simon. "One-Man Riot Squad." ''[[American Cinematographer]]'' Volume 88, issue 7, July 2007. p. 32.</ref> to significantly dramatize its hovering ability using the lift fan.
The Transformers character of the Autobot [[Breakaway (Transformers)#Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen|Breakaway]] and its redeco the Decepticon [[Thrust (Transformers)#Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen|Thrust]] from the ''Revenge of the Fallen'' toy both disguise themselves as F-35s. Breakaway appears as a playable character in the 2009 ''[[Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen (video game)|Revenge of the Fallen]]'' video game.<ref name="BWTFF35">{{cite web |url= http://www.bwtf.com/toyreviews/rotf/deluxe/breakaway |title= Revenge of the Fallen Breakaway Toy Review |accessdate= 2010-02-20 |last= Yee |first= Benson |authorlink= |year= 2009 |month= May}}</ref>
==F-86 Sabre== USAF fighter pilot love story, the 1958 film ''[[The Hunters (1958 film)|The Hunters]]'', set in Korea, features [[North American F-86 Sabre]]s.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsH">{{cite web |url= http://www.aerofiles.com/film-h.html |title= Aviation Films - H |accessdate= 8 May 2010 |last= Aerofiles |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref>
Desmond Bagley's book ''High Citadel'' features F-86 Sabres, which make up the frontline equipment of the air force of the fictional South American country in which the book is set. There are four squadrons of Sabres; two are loyal to the current corrupt government; one is secretly loyal to a reformist politician who is returning from exile to take over the country; and the fourth is secretly loyal to Communist forces who are attempting to kill the politician. The Indian (Hindi) film, [[Rang De Basanti]] (2006), depicted the MiG-21.<ref name="TOI_after_viewing">{{cite news |accessdate=2008-03-23 |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/msid-1366390,prtpage-1.cms |title=AF gives all clear signal to Aamir's Rang de Basanti |date=2006-01-10 |work=The Times of India}}</ref>
==Mikoyan MiG-29== The [[Mikoyan MiG-29]] is the alternate form of the figure [[Dreadwing]] as well as its [[redeco]]s [[Overcast (Transformers)|Overcast]] and [[Fearswoop]] from the 2007 and 2009 ''[[Transformers (film)|Transformers]]'' film toy lines.<ref name="Overcast">{{cite web |url= http://www.bwtf.com/toyreviews/movie2007/overcast |title= Transformers 2007 Movie Overcast Toy Review |accessdate= 2010-01-19 |last= Yee |first= Benson |authorlink= |year= 2008}}</ref>
==Mil Mi-24== In the film ''[[Air Force One (film)|Air Force One]]'' a [[Mil Mi-24 Hind]] helicopter is sent to retrieve one of the antagonists, from a Russian prison.<ref name="RotaryactionA" />
A Mi-24 helicopter was also used in the film ''[[Blood Diamond (film)|Blood Diamond]]'', to attack a revolutionaries jungle base in [[Sierra Leone]].<ref name="RotaryactionB">[http://www.rotaryaction.com/b.html Rotary Action - B]</ref>
==N3N Canary== [[Naval Aircraft Factory N3N Canary]]s were shown in the 1941 [[Warner Bros.]] film ''[[Dive Bomber (film)|Dive Bomber]]''.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsD" />
==Nakajima Ki-27== [[Nakajima Ki-27]]s, lifted from Japanese film, appeared in the 1942 [[Republic Pictures|Republic]] film ''[[Flying Tigers (film)|Flying Tigers]].<ref name="FlyingTigersFilms">{{cite web |url= http://www.warbirdforum.com/movies.htm |title= Flying Tiger films, past and possible |accessdate= 11 May 2010 |last =Ford |first= Daniel |authorlink= |year= 2009 |month= November}}</ref>
==Nieuport 17== The [[Nieuport 17]] was one of the main aircraft featured in the film ''[[Flyboys (film)|Flyboys]]''.<ref name="Briggs">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4547873.stm |title=Actors learn to fly for war film |last=Briggs |first=Caroline |date=May 14, 2005 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="Talcott">{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/21/AR2006092100453.html |title='Flyboy' Rises Above Villainous Past |last=Talcott |first=Christina |date=September 22, 2006 |publisher=Washington Post |accessdate=12 January 2010}}</ref>
==Nieuport 28==
An authentic [[Nieuport 28]] was provided and flown by [[Frank Tallman]], a [[Hollywood]] stunt pilot, for the ''[[The Twilight Zone]]'' episode [[The Last Flight (The Twilight Zone)|"The Last Flight"]] in which a World War I Royal Flying Corps pilot is transported in time in a cloud to the 1960s. [[Norton AFB]], California, was the filming site. The episode first aired on 5 February 1960. <ref>Zicree, Marc Scott, "The Twilight Zone Companion", Bantam Books, 1982.</ref>
==Noorduyn AT-16== Canadian-built variants of the [[North American T-6 Texan]] are seen in the 1943 [[RKO]] film ''[[Bombardier (film)|Bombardier]]'', filmed at [[Kirtland Field]], New Mexico.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsB" />
==Noorduyn Norseman== The [[Noorduyn Norseman]] is featured in scenes in the 1942 [[Warner Bros.]] film ''[[Captains of the Clouds]]'', with [[Jimmy Cagney]] as a [[Canadian]] [[bush pilot]] at the start of World War II.<ref>[http://projectpi.skydiveworld.com/PI-norseman.htm Noorduyn Norseman]. projectpi.skydiveworld.com</ref>
==North American AT-6 Texan== The 1941 [[Paramount Pictures]] film ''[[I Wanted Wings]]'' featured flights of upwards of 50 [[North American T-6 Texan]]s from [[Kelly Field]], Texas. [[Paul Mantz]] flew camera ships.<ref name="CoastComp" />
==North American BT-9 / BT-16== [[North American BT-9]] and BT-16 basic trainers were filmed at [[Randolph Field]], Texas, for the 1941 [[Paramount Pictures]] film ''[[I Wanted Wings]]'', based on the novel of the same title by 1st Lt. [[Beirne Lay, Jr.]]. [[Paul Mantz]] flew camera ships.<ref name="CoastComp" />
==North American X-15== [[File:X-15 in flight.jpg|thumb|right|[[North American X-15]] ]]
On 5 November 1959, a small engine fire forced pilot [[Scott Crossfield]] to make an emergency landing on [[Rosamond Dry Lake]], [[Edwards AFB]], California, in [[X-15]], ''56-6671''. Not designed to land with fuel on board, test craft came down with a heavy load of propellants and broke its back, grounding this particular X-15 for three months. Footage of this accident was later incorporated in [[The Outer Limits (1963 TV series)|The Outer Limits]] episode "''[[The Premonition]]''", first aired 9 January 1965.<ref>[http://area51specialprojects.com/x-15_crashes.html X-15 Crashes and Mission Chronology]</ref>
==Northrop A-17== The [[Northrop A-17]] makes an appearance at [[March Field]] at the conclusion of the 1941 [[Paramount Pictures]] film ''[[I Wanted Wings]]''.<ref name="CoastComp" />
==Northrop YB-49== Archival footage was used to depict [[Northrop YB-49]]s attacking the Martians with atomic weapons in the 1953 film ''[[The War of the Worlds (1953 film)|The War of the Worlds]]''.<ref>[http://www.cedmagic.com/featured/war-worlds/flying-wing.html Northrop YB-49 Flying Wing]</ref>
==O-1 Bird Dog== The 1990 film ''[[Air America (film)|Air America]]'', which loosely recounted the exploits of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] proprietary airline in Southeast Asia in the 1960s and early '70s, featured [[Cessna O-1 Bird Dog]]s.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsA" />
==O-2 Skymaster== An unmodified [[Cessna Skymaster|Cessna 337 Skymaster]] painted gray played the part of a [[Cessna O-2 Skymaster]] in the motion picture ''[[Bat*21]]'', as the plane flown by [[Danny Glover]].<ref name="IMDBBat21O2">{{cite web |url= http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094712/ |title= Bat*21 |accessdate= 2009-10-31 |last= [[Internet Movie Data Base]] |authorlink= |year= 2009}}</ref>
==O2C Helldiver== U.S. Navy [[Curtiss Falcon|Curtiss O2C-2 Helldiver]]s from [[Floyd Bennett Field]] were used in filming ''[[King Kong (1933)|King Kong]]'' in 1933, but as [[Carl Denham]] observed, "Oh no, it wasn't the airplanes. It was beauty killed the beast." Writer and director [[Merian C. Cooper]] portrayed the pilot who kills Kong, in an uncredited role.<ref name="tcm.com"/>
==OH-6 Cayuse / Hughes 500== Three [[Hughes OH-6 Cayuse|Hughes OH-6A Cayuse]] helicopters make up part of the strike package against [[Ernst Stavro Blofeld]]'s oil rig command center in the 1971 [[James Bond]] film ''[[Diamonds Are Forever (film)|Diamonds Are Forever]]''.<ref name="rotaryaction.com"/>
A [[Hughes 500]] takes part in the film ''Birds Of Prey'', where a traffic reporter, played by [[David Janssen]], gets into an aerial duel with a gang of bank robbers, who have their own get away helicopter, an [[Alouette II]]<ref>[http://www.rotaryaction.com/pages/birdsprey.html Rotary Action - Birds Of Prey]</ref>
A pair of Hughes 500 helicopters appear in the film ''[[Capricorn One]]'', near the climatic ending where they get entangled with a crop duster biplane.<ref name="RotaryActionC">[http://www.rotaryaction.com/c.html Rotary Action - C]</ref>
[[MH-6 Little Bird]] helicopters show up in the film ''[[Black Hawk Down (film)|Black Hawk Down]]'' as air support for the downed Blackhawk crew.<ref>[http://www.rotaryaction.com/pages/blackhawk.html Rotary Action - Blackhawk Down]</ref>
In the television series [[Magnum, P.I.]] Thomas Magnum's friend and also war veteran Theodore Calvin (also T.C.) flies a civilian Hughes 500D as a tourist charter Island Hoppers business.<ref Name="RotaryM" />
==P-1 Hawk== The 1927 [[William Wellman]] film [[Wings (film)|''Wings'']] featured [[Curtiss P-1 Hawk]]s amongst many types depicting [[World War I]] aircraft.<ref name="historynet1"/>
==P-35== A civilianized [[Seversky P-35]], the Seversky S2, which won the 1937 [[Bendix Trophy]] race, appeared as the "Drake Bullet" in the 1938 [[M-G-M]] film [[Test Pilot (film)|''Test Pilot'']].<ref>[http://aerostories.free.fr/severskyP35/page11.html Seversky P-35's unexpected metamorphosis]</ref>
==P-38 Lightning== ''[[Von Ryan's Express]]'' (1965) begins with main protagonist, USAAF Colonel Joseph Ryan ([[Frank Sinatra]]) crash landing a [[Lockheed P-38 Lightning]] in World War II Italy, where he was held as a prisoner of war.<ref>[http://cmulrooney.tripod.com/robson.html Von Ryanâs Express]</ref>
''[[A Guy Named Joe]]'' (1943) has [[Spencer Tracy]] returning as a guiding spirit looking after young P-38 pilot [[Van Johnson]].<ref>Hardwick, Jack and Ed Schnepf. "A Viewer's Guide to Aviation Movies." ''The Making of the Great Aviation Films''. General Aviation Series, Volume 2, 1989</ref>
The 1944 short feature ''P-38 Reconnaissance Pilot'', starring [[William Holden]] as Lt. "Packy" Cummings, dramatises the work of photo [[reconnaissance]] pilots in World War II.<ref name="P-38ReccePlt">{{cite web |url= http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_0dn4COqsoY |title =Reconnaissance Pilot |accessdate= 2010-02-23 |last= You Tube |authorlink= |year= 2010 |month= February}}</ref>
==P-40== [[File:Hells Angels, Flying Tigers 1942.jpg|thumb|right|[[Curtiss P-40 Warhawk]]s]]
In the [[John Wayne]] film: ''[[Flying Tigers (film)|Flying Tigers]]'', (1942) real [[Curtiss P-40 Warhawk]]s are featured. A New York Times critic called the P-40 "the true stars" of the film.<ref name="Van Gelder">{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/22/tv/movies-this-week-441961.html |title=Movies this week |last=Van Gelder |first=Lawrence |date=September 22, 1996 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=10 February 2010}}</ref> Republic Studios also built replicas for the film due to material shortages during the war. These can be identified by the fairings hiding the cylinder heads of the automotive V-8 engines installed in them.<ref name="Church">{{cite web |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AcwaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=f0wEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3580,1545824&dq=film+flying-tigers&hl=en |title=Film Makers Learn to Share |last=Church |first=Harlow |date=January 6, 1943 |publisher=Pittsburgh Press |page=21 |accessdate=10 February 2010}}</ref>
Future U.S. President [[Ronald Reagan]] appears in the ''Identification Of The Japanese Zero (Training Film)'' (1942) as a young pilot learning to recognize the difference between a P-40 and a Japanese Zero. In this film Reagan mistakes a friend's P-40 for a Japanese Zero and tries to shoot it down. In the end, Reagan gets a chance to shoot down a real Zero.<ref>[http://www.ihffilm.com/22039.html Ronald Reagan - Identification of the Japanese Zero (Training Film)]</ref>
In the film ''[[God is My Co-Pilot (film)|God is My Co-Pilot]]'' (1945), based on Robert Lee Scott, Jr's book about the Flying Tigers and the USAAF pilots who replaced them in the [[Republic of China]] and [[Burma]], a mix of real P-40 and "film" P-40s are featured.<ref name="SPTime">{{cite web |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=OlAwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xk4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=7467,4139418&dq=film+flying-tigers&hl=en |title=Film Tribute to Air Heroes |date=April 21, 1945 |publisher=St. Pete Times |accessdate=10 February 2010}}</ref>
In ''Tora! Tora! Tora!'', P-40s are depicted at the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]], both being shot up on the ground and shooting down Zeros.<ref>Hathaway, John. "Tora! Tora! Tora!" Flying Review, Vol. 25, No. 3, July 1969 p. 52.</ref> <!-- See [[List of fictional aircraft]] for P-40 like fighter seen in [[Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow]] film. -->
In [[Steven Spielberg]]'s film [[1941 (film)|''1941'']], a P-40 Tomahawk was used as actor [[John Belushi]]'s fighter, with scenes at the "Barstow Munitions Depot" filmed at [[Ventura County, California#Entertainment|Indian Dunes, California]].<ref>[http://www.dvdtalk.com/dvdsavant/s681941.html 1941 - A Giant Comedy - Only With Guns!]</ref>
==P-47 Thunderbolt== The film ''[[Fighter Squadron]]'' (1948) depicts a [[Republic P-47 Thunderbolt]] unit.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0040353/ "Fighter Squadron (1948)."] ''imdb.com''. Retrieved: 21 November 2009.</ref>
Czech composer [[Bohuslav MartinÅ¯]] paid a tribute to the aircraft with his [[scherzo]] for orchestra. It was premiered 19 December 1945 in [[Washington, D.C.]].<ref>VojtÃ¡Å¡ek, Filip. [http://hloubkari.bloguje.cz/567713-bohuslav-martinu-napsal-skladbu-nazvanou-p-47-thunderbolt.php "Bohuslav MartinÅ¯ napsal skladbu nazvanou P-47 Thunderbolt (Bohuslav MartinÅ¯ composed a scherzo titled P-47 Thunderbolt) (in Czech)."] ''Hloubkari.cz'', 27 July 2007. [[Steve Earle]]'s song "Johnny Come Lately" is about an American P-47 pilot in World War II; it contains a verse "My P-47 is a pretty good ship. Modified [[T-6 Texan]]s depicted P-47s in the film ''[[A Bridge Too Far (film)|A Bridge Too Far]]''.<ref name="Hurst, Flt 1977, p. 33-34" />
==P-51 Mustang== The [[North American P-51 Mustang]] was featured in the film ''[[The Tuskegee Airmen]]''.<ref name="Armstrong">{{cite web |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/lifestyle/106517_fam31.shtml |title=Tuskegee Airmen seek a 'double victory' |last=Armstrong |first=Doree |date=July 31, 2003 |publisher=Seattle Post-Intelligencer |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref>
Two P-51Ds appear briefly at the end of ''[[Saving Private Ryan]]'' as "tank-busters" (although P-47 Thunderbolts would have been the more likely type in this role). "Big Beautiful Doll" of the Old Flying Machine Company, [[Cambridge, England]], and "Old Crow" of the Scandinavian Historic Flight were used.<ref>[http://www.sproe.com/p/plane-p51-mustang.html P-51D Mustang IV]</ref>
P-51s feature repeatedly in the film ''[[Empire of the Sun (film)|Empire of the Sun]]'', dubbed the "cadillac of the skies" by the protagonist, as a symbol of America in the Chinese theatre of World War II.<ref>[http://www.p51models.com/cadillac-of-the-skies-on-empire-of-the-sun/ Cadillac of the Skies on Empire of the Sun]. p51models.com</ref>
P-51 Mustangs (post war designation F-51D) appear in the 1957 film ''[[Battle Hymn]]''.<ref name="Hardwick 1989"/>
==Panavia Tornado== The Royal Air Force's ground attack aircraft, the [[Panavia Tornado]], featured extensively in the television pilot Strike Force, produced in the 1990s for ITV in the UK. Strike Force did not enter series production.<ref name="Strike Force">{{cite web |url= http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/529442?view=synopsis |title= Strike Force (1995 television pilot) |accessdate= 2010-02-22 |last= BFI library |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref>
The Transformers character [[Darkwing (Transformers)|Darkwing]] disguises himself as a Panavia Tornado.<ref>Transformers Identification and Price Guide by Mark Bellomo, 2007, p. 199.</ref>
==PBY Catalina== A former [[Royal Danish Air Force]] [[Consolidated PBY Catalina|Consolidated PBY-6A Catalina]], BuNo ''63998'', civil registered N16KL, later owned by the [[Confederate Air Force]]' Lone Star Wing, appeared in the 1976 film [[Midway (film)|''Midway'']]. This airframe was subsequently written off in a fatal crash on 13 October 1984.<ref>[http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19841013-0 Accident description 13 OCT 1984 Consolidated PBY-6A Catalina]</ref><ref name="Legg">Legg, David, "Consolidated PBY Catalina: The Peacetime Record", Naval Institute Press, Annapolis, Maryland, 2002, Library of Congress card number 2001090501, ISBN 1-55750-245-5, pp. 257, 266.</ref>
PBY-5A Catalina, BuNo ''34027'', registered N9505C, appeared in the opening sequence of the 1989 [[Steven Spielberg]] film [[Always (1989 film)|''Always'']] as a firebomber picking up a water load and bearing down on two startled fisherman.<ref name="Legg" />
In the 2002 submarine film ''[[Below (film)|Below]]'', the USS Tiger Shark is directed to pick up three survivors of a torpedoed hospital ship by a Consolidated PBY-5A Catalina, marked as ''AH545'', 'WQ-Z' of 209 Squadron. PBY-5A N9521C was marked as the Catalina that had a decisive role in the sinking of the ''Bismarck''.<ref>Crouchman, Alan F., "'''Cat' Gets Movie Role''", Flypast, Stamford, Lincs., September 2001, No. 242, p. 7.</ref>
A Catalina also appeared in [[Clive Cussler]]'s 1973 novel, [[The Mediterranean Caper]].<ref name="MedCaper" />
The 1973 film [[Steelyard Blues]] starring Donald Sutherland and Jane Fonda centres on at attempt to make a Catalina airworthy.<ref>http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0070731/</ref>
==PB4Y Privateer== U.S. Navy [[PB4Y Privateer|PB4Y-2M Privateer]]s of [[VP-23]], based at [[Naval Air Station Miami]], Florida, were filmed at the close of the 1948 hurricane season and the footage used in the 1949 [[20th Century-Fox]] film "''[[Slattery's Hurricane]]''".<ref name="vp23">{{cite web |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year= |url= http://www.vpnavy.com/adobe/vp_23.pdf |title= Third VP-23 |format= |work =DICTIONARY OF AMERICAN NAVAL AVIATION SQUADRONSâVolume 2 |publisher= U.S. Navy |accessdate= 20 September 2009}}, p. 143.</ref>
==Percival Proctor== [[File:Percival Proctor V Manchester 1953.jpg|thumb|right|[[Percival Proctor]] ]]
The most prominent of the real aircraft in Nevil Shute's ''Round the Bend'' is a war-surplus [[Percival Proctor]], which is used by the protagonist Constantine Shak Lin (also known as Connie Shaklin) to tour Asia to spread his teachings. At the end of the book the Proctor is the basis of a shrine to Shaklin and his new creed, laid up in a hangar in a state of uncompleted maintenance for pilgrims to view.<ref name="Round the Bend">{{cite book |last=Shute |first=Nevil |title=Round the Bend |publisher=Pan |location=London |year=1968 |pages= |isbn=0-330-02018-8}}</ref>
In 1951 Captain W.E. Johns had Biggles and his team fly 2 Percival Proctors in the story "Another Job For Biggles".<ref>Johns, Capt. W.E. ''Another Job For Biggles''. London: H&S, 1951</ref>
In 1968, three Proctors were remodelled with [[Gull wing|inverted gull wings]] and other cosmetic alterations to represent [[Junkers Ju 87]]s in the film ''Battle of Britain''.<ref>Jackson, A.J. ''British Civil Aircraft since 1919, Volume 3''. London: Putnam, 1974. ISBN 0-370-10006-9.</ref>
==Pfalz D.XII== A [[Pfalz D.XII]] which is now in the [[National Air and Space Museum]], Washington, D.C., was flown in [[The Dawn Patrol (1930 film)|''The Dawn Patrol'']] (1930), [[Hell's Angels (film)|''Hell's Angels'']] (1930), and ''[[Men with Wings]]'' (1938).<ref name="rogerdarlington1"/>
==Pilatus Porter== The STOL-capable [[Pilatus Porter]] was depicted in the 1990 film ''[[Air America (film)|Air America]]'', loosely recounting the exploits of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] proprietary airline in Southeast Asia in the 1960s and early '70s.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsA" />
==Piper Cherokee== The character [[Pussy Galore]] in the ''James Bond'' film ''[[Goldfinger (film)|Goldfinger]]'' is the leader of "Pussy Galore's Flying Circus", a group of women who fly [[Piper Cherokee]]s. In the film the arch-villain uses the Cherokees in his plan to deprive the United States government of the gold in [[United States Bullion Depository|Fort Knox]].<ref name="MI6">{{cite web |url=http://www.mi6.co.uk/sections/movies/gf_synopsis.php3?t=mi6&s=gf |title=Goldfinger synopsis |last= |first= |date=Undated |publisher=MI6 - The Home of James Bond 007 |accessdate=6 February 2010}}</ref><ref name="Lande">{{cite web |url=http://www.airspacemag.com/history-of-flight/Live_and_Let_Fly.html |title=Live and Let Fly: Real pilots rate the performance of the airplanes in James Bond flicks |last=Lande |first=David |date=September 1, 2008 |publisher=Air & Space/Smithsonian |accessdate=6 February 2010}}</ref>
==Pitcairn Autogyro== In the 1934 screwball comedy ''[[It Happened One Night]]'', the foppish bridegroom King Westley arrives at his own wedding "piloting" a [[Pitcairn Aircraft Company]] [[autogyro]] (although the real pilot can be seen crouching in the cockpit after Westley deplanes).<ref>[http://www.dailyscript.com/scripts/It_Happened_one_night.html IT HAPPENED ONCE NIGHT - Screenplay by Robert Riskin]</ref><ref>[http://www.filmsite.org/itha4.html It Happened One Night (1934)]</ref><ref>[http://midnightoil.squarespace.com/it-happened-one-night-1934/ It Happened One Night (1934)]</ref>
==Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5== The 1927 [[William Wellman]] film [[Wings (film)|''Wings'']] featured a [[Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5]]a amongst many types depicting [[World War I]] aircraft.<ref name="historynet1"/>
==Ryan NYP== The 1938 [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]] film ''[[Men with Wings]]'', starring [[Ray Milland]], featured a reproduction of the ''[[Spirit of St. Louis]]'' fashioned from a [[Ryan Brougham|Ryan B-1 Brougham]].<ref>Cassagneres, Ev. ''The Untold Story of the Spirit of St. Louis: From the Drawing Board to the Smithsonian''. New Brighton, Minnesota: Flying Book International, 2002. ISBN 0-911139-32-X, p. 140.</ref>
A recreation of the [[Ryan NYP]] was used for the 1957 [[Warner Bros.]] film ''[[The Spirit of St. Louis (film)|The Spirit of St. Louis]]'', starring [[Jimmy Stewart]] as [[Charles Lindbergh]].<ref>Simpson, Rod, "Preserving the Spirit", ''Air-Britain Aviation World'', Volume 55, no. 4, 2003, ISSN 0950-7434, p. 66.</ref>
==SB2C Helldiver / A-25 Shrike== Two USAAF [[Curtiss SB2C Helldiver|Curtiss RA-25A Shrike]]s collided during a [[flypast]] for an air show near [[Spokane, Washington]] on 23 July 1944, the accident filmed by a [[Paramount Pictures]] newsreel crew. This footage was used in the 1956 film ''[[Earth vs. the Flying Saucers]]'', apparently being shot down by a saucer.<ref>[http://www.check-six.com/lib/Movie_Crash.htm Movie Crash from Earth vs. the Flying Saucers 23 July 1944]. check-six.com</ref>
==SB2U Vindicator== [[Vought SB2U Vindicator]]s were featured in the 1941 [[Warner Bros.]] film ''Dive Bomber''.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsD" />
==Sikorsky SH-3 Sea King== CIA officer [[Jack Ryan (Tom Clancy)|Jack Ryan]] (played by [[Alec Baldwin]]) is flown from an aircraft carrier to the submarine [[USS Dallas (SSN-700)|USS ''Dallas'']] in a [[Sikorsky SH-3 Sea King|Sikorsky SH-3H Sea King]] in the 1990 film ''[[Hunt for Red October (film)|Hunt for Red October]]'', based on the [[Tom Clancy]] novel of the same title.<ref name="RotaryActionSH3" />
At the end of the successful rescue mission for ''[[Apollo 13 (film)|Apollo 13]]'', two SH-3 Sea Kings, historically painted as Helos ''66'' and ''406'', retrieve the astronauts from their spacecraft after splashdown in the 1995 [[Ron Howard]] film.<ref name="RotaryactionA" />
==Sikorsky H-5 / HO3S / Dragonfly== [[File:Sikorsky YH-5A USAF.jpg|thumb|right|[[Sikorsky H-5]] ]]
The 1954 film ''[[The Bridges at Toko-Ri]]'', based on the 1953 [[James A. Michener]] novella of the same title, opens and closes with scenes of a [[U.S. Navy]] [[Sikorsky H-5|Sikorsky HO3S-1]] of utility helicopter squadron HU-1 operating from an [[Essex class]] aircraft carrier in pilot rescue and recovery during the [[Korean War]].<ref name="coastcompfilm" />
==Sikorsky H-19 / Westland Whirlwind== The character of [[Harold the Helicopter]] from the British children's program [[Thomas the Tank Engine]] is based on the [[Sikorsky H-19|Sikorsky S-55]], built in the UK as the [[Westland Whirlwind (helicopter)|Westland Whirlwind]].<ref name="Harold">{{cite web |url= http://www.pegnsean.net/~railwayseries/harold.htm |title= Harold the Helicopter |accessdate= 7 June 2010 |last= Clutterbuck |first= Martin |authorlink= |year= }}</ref>
==Sikorsky S-64== In the film ''[[Independence Day (film)|Independence Day]]'' a [[Sikorsky S-64]] Skycrane is fitted with an array of flashing lights to communicate with an alien spaceship.<ref>[http://www.rotaryaction.com/i.html Rotary Action - I]</ref>
A Skycrane also appears in the film ''[[Swordfish (film)|Swordfish]]'', near the climatic ending in which it has a bus full of hostages slung loaded underneath, and is flying through downtown [[Los Angeles]].<ref>[http://www.rotaryaction.com/pages/swordfish.html Swordfish (2001)]</ref>
==Sikorsky H-53 series== The [[Sikorsky MH-53]] is also featured in the [[Transformers (film)|2007 ''Transformers'' film]] as the alternate mode of [[Blackout (Transformers)|Blackout]].
