The heavier [[CH-53E Super Stallion]] is the alternate form for the [[Decepticon]] [[Grindor]] in the film ''[[Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen]]''.<ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/motoring/wheelsonfilm/5711162/Wheels-On-Film-Transformers-Revenge-Of-The-Fallen.html "Wheels On Film: Transformers: Revenge Of The Fallen"]. Telegraph.co.uk, 6 July 2009.</ref>
The Super Stallion also appeared in the film ''The Sum of All Fears''.<ref name="Seelye"/>
==Sikorsky H-60 series== The [[Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk]] was the title aircraft in the film ''[[Black Hawk Down (film)|Black Hawk Down]]''.<ref name="Cappiello">{{cite web |url=http://trib.com/news/state-and-regional/article_9af0c1a4-ceff-554b-b9be-0e77e1cc0ebe.html |title=Survivor credits instinct |last=Cappiello |first=Vince |date=June 4, 2003 |publisher=Casper Star-Tribune |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref> Film makers paid the U.S. Department of Defense about $3 million to ship eight helicopters and about 100 crew members to the film location in Morocco.<ref name="Seelye"/>
Black Hawks were also featured in the film ''"Air Force One"'', again having been rented from the U.S. military.<ref name="Times-AFO" />
In the film ''[[Clear and Present Danger (film)|Clear and Present Danger]]'' a pair of [[Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk|MH-60L Blackhawks]] are used to deploy a special ops team, into a [[Colombia]]n jungle.<ref name="RotaryActionC" />
==Sopwith Camel== [[File:Sopwith F-1 Camel USAF.jpg|thumb|right|[[Sopwith Camel]] ]]
The First World War [[Sopwith Camel]] fighter features prominently in the ''[[Biggles]]'' stories of W E Johns such as the collections: ''The Camels Are Coming'',<ref name="Camel01">{{cite web |url= http://www.biggles.info/Details/01/ |title= The Camels are Coming |accessdate= 2010-01-12 |last= Harris |first= Roger |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref> and ''Biggles of the Camel Squadron''.<ref name="Camel02">{{cite web |url= http://www.biggles.info/Details/03/ |title= Biggles of the Camel Squadron |accessdate= 2010-01-12 |last= Harris |first= Roger |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref>
In the film ''[[The Great Waldo Pepper]]'' the title character, flying a Camel, takes part in a dogfight with a [[Fokker Dr.I]].<ref name="WaldoPepper">{{cite web |url= http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0073075/usercomments |title= The Great Waldo Pepper (1975) |accessdate= 18 May 2010 |last= Frisina |first= Scott A. |authorlink= |year= 1999 |month= August}}</ref>
==Space Shuttle orbiter==
The Transformers Combaticon named Blast Off and the Autobot [[Sky Lynx]] both disguise themselves as [[Space Shuttle orbiter]]s.<ref>Bellomo, Mark. ''Transformers Identification and Price Guide'', 2007. pp. 101, 112.</ref>
==SPAD== The 1927 [[William Wellman]] film [[Wings (film)|''Wings'']] featured a [[SPAD S.VII]] amongst many types depicting [[World War I]] aircraft.<ref name="historynet1"/>
[[Race Bannon]], flying a [[SPAD S.XIII]], fights a dogfight with a [[Fokker D.VII]], flown by Baron Heinrich von Frohleich in Episode 10 of ''[[Jonny Quest (TV series)|Jonny Quest]]'', "[[List of Jonny Quest episodes|Shadow of the Condor]]".<ref name="QuestList" />
==SR-71 Blackbird== In the 1985 film [[D.A.R.Y.L.]] the protagonist steals an [[SR-71 Blackbird]] from an air base while trying to escape from government agents.<ref name="SARYL"> {{Cite web|url= http://www.moviemonday.com/ScienceFiction/tn5.htm|title= D.A.R.Y.L (A-)|accessdate= 23 August 2011|last= MovieMonday.com|year= undated}}</ref>
The [[Lockheed SR-71 Blackbird]] at the [[March Field Air Museum]] was prominently featured in a scene in the 2000 film ''[[Space Cowboys]]''.<ref name="MarchCollection">[http://www.marchfield.org/collect.html March Field Collection]. marchfield.org</ref>
Although retired from service for over a decade, the SR-71 Blackbird appears in form of the character [[Jetfire]], an over-the-hill Transformer near the end of its days, in the film ''Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen'' and its toy line, which are SR-71 models.<ref name="HasbroJetfire">{{cite web |url= http://www.hasbro.com/shop/details.cfm?guid=38049C09-19B9-F369-D906-BE5F6E2B12F7&product_id=24498&src=endeca |title= TRANSFORMERS: REVENGE OF THE FALLEN - Leader JETFIRE |accessdate= 2009-12-09 |last= Hasbro |authorlink= |year= 2008}} </ref>
==Stampe SV.4== The 1976 film [[Aces High (film)|Aces High]] uses several modified [[Stampe SV.4]] aircraft made to look like [[Royal Flying Corps]] [[Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5]] aircraft. These aircraft were prepared by Bianchi Aviation Film Services and flown by well known pilots including [[Neil Williams (pilot)|Neil Williams]].<ref>[http://www.bianchiaviation.com/main_nn.htm Welcome to the world of flying for motion pictures]</ref><ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075627/fullcredits#cast Full cast and crew for Aces High (1976)]. IMDB</ref>
==Supermarine Spitfire==
The 1942 film ''[[The First of the Few]]'' is a dramatization of the life of [[R. J. Mitchell]], mostly concerning his work on the [[Supermarine Spitfire]].<ref name="ArchiveFew">{{cite web |url= http://www.archive.org/details/TheFirstOfTheFew |title= The First of the Few |accessdate= 28 April 2010 |last= Howard |first= Leslie |authorlink= |year= 1942}}</ref><ref name="BritMovieFew">{{cite web |url= http://www.britmovie.co.uk/films/The-First-of-the-Few |title= The First of the Few |accessdate= 28 April 2010 |last= Britmovie.co.uk |authorlink= |year= 2010}}</ref>
The Spitfire was a central part of the film ''[[Battle of Britain (film)|Battle of Britain]]'', a fictionalized account of the real [[Battle of Britain]] that one critic called "the definitive depiction of war in the air".<ref name="Burman"/> The film led to an increase in the popularity of the aircraft among collectors of [[warbird]]s. According to one property dealer the appearance "did for Spitfires what the James Bond films did for the Aston Martin."<ref name="McSmith">{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10567818 |title=Killer looks seduce property man |last=McSmith |first=Andy |date=April 22, 2009 |publisher=NZ Hearld |accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref> Producers secured 35 Spitfires for use in the film.<ref name="Burman"/>
The Spitfire was also the main aircraft used in the 1988 television series ''[[Piece of Cake (TV series)|Piece of Cake]]''. The series was based on [[Piece of Cake (novel)|a novel by the same name]]. Pilots in the novel flew the Hawker Hurricane, but the lack of airworthy Hurricanes forced the producers to change aircraft types, using five reconditioned Spitfires.<ref name="Voorhees">{{cite news |url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19900706&slug=1080871 |title=It's Easy To Get Up About Something Like `Piece Of Cake' |last=Voorhees |first=John |date=July 6, 1990 |publisher=Seattle Times |accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref>
The 1951 film ''[[Malta Story]]'' centered around Spitfires and their pilots defending Malta in 1942.<ref name="Ward">{{cite web |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BeMeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=y00EAAAAIBAJ&pg=7289,1061476&dq=film+spitfire+aircraft+%7C+plane+-grill&hl=en |title=Alec Guiness stars in Malta Story |last=Ward |first=Henry |date=August 6, 1955 |publisher=Pittsburgh Press |accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref>
In [[John Frankenheimer]]'s 1964 film, ''[[The Train (1964 film)|The Train]]'', a Royal Air Force Spitfire is shown attempting to shoot up a locomotive traveling light which gains safety in a tunnel. The helicopter filming the sequence was almost struck by the fighter during the shot.<ref>[http://www.tcm.com/thismonth/article/?cid=79855 TCM This Month - The Train]</ref>
A Spitfire Mk. IXc, ''MH434'', depicted an aerial reconnaissance variant in ''[[A Bridge Too Far (film)|A Bridge Too Far]]''. It was flown by Neil Williams.<ref>Hurst, Flt. Lt. K.J., DC-3 Project Officer for the film; ''[[Air International]]'', July 1977, Volume 13, Number 1, pp. 33-34, Talkback column</ref>
==Supermarine Swift== The second prototype [[Supermarine Swift]] appeared as the "Prometheus" in the 1952 film ''[[The Sound Barrier]]''.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsB" /><ref>{{cite book |title= Supermarine Aircraft since 1914 |last= Andrews |first= CF |coauthors= Morgan, EB |edition= 2nd |year= 1987 |publisher= Putnam |location= London |isbn= 0-85177-800-3 |page=284}}</ref>
==TBD Devastator== [[Douglas TBD Devastator]]s were featured in the 1941 [[Warner Bros.]] film ''[[Dive Bomber (film)|Dive Bomber]]''.<ref name="AerofilesFilmsD" />
==Thomas-Morse MB-3== The 1927 [[William Wellman]] film [[Wings (film)|''Wings'']] featured [[Thomas-Morse MB-3|Thomas-Morse MB-3As]] amongst many types depicting [[World War I]] aircraft.<ref name="historynet1"/>
==Thurston Teal== [[File:Thurston TSC-1 Teal N897TB Lakeland FL 22.04.09R.jpg|thumb|right|[[Thurston Teal]] ]]
A [[Thurston Teal|Teal TSC 1A1]] appears in the long opening shots of the 1973 film ''[[The Wicker Man (1973 film)|The Wicker Man]]''.<ref>[http://www.caa.co.uk/application.aspx?catid=60&pagetype=65&appid=1&mode=detailnosummary&fullregmark=AXZN The registration is clearly visible as G-AZXN]</ref>
==UFM Easy Riser== The [[UFM Easy Riser]] was one of two ultralight aircraft that lead the [[Canada geese]] south in the film ''[[Fly Away Home]]''. The film was a highly fictionalized account based on [[Bill Lishman]]'s autobiography and work with [[Operation Migration]], but both Lishman's real-life migratory experiments teaching birds to migrate and the film used the Easy Riser, due to its low cruising speed, which allowed the birds to pace the aircraft in flight.<ref name="Lishman">{{Cite web |url= http://williamlishman.com/flight.htm |title= Ultralight aircraft |accessdate= 9 March 2011 |last= Name |first= Name |authorlink= |year= undated}}</ref><ref name="EbertFlyway">{{Cite news |url= http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19960913/REVIEWS/609130303/1023 |title= Fly Away Home |accessdate= 9 March 2011 |last= Ebert |first= Roger |authorlink= |year= 1996 |month= September |work=Chicago Sun-Times}}</ref>
==Vickers Valiant== The [[Vickers Valiant]] figures in [[Hank Searls|Anthony Gray]]'s 1965 novel ''The Penetrators'', in which an [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] officer attempts to demonstrate a weakness in the North American strategic defense system [[NORAD]] by launching a mock attack involving nine [[Avro Vulcan]]s and some Vickers Valiant tankers for [[inflight refuelling]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Vickers Wellington==
The [[Vickers Wellington]] features in the films ''[[Target for Tonight]]''<ref>Crowther, Bosley, [http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9807E0DB163DE333A2575BC1A9669D946093D6CF "Target for Tonight (1941) 'Target for Tonight,' a Fine Fact Film About the R.A.F."], New York Times, 18 October 1941</ref> and ''[[One of Our Aircraft Is Missing]]'' which both depict the different fortunes of [[RAF]] crews on bombing raids over Germany.
A haunted Vickers Wellington is the subject of [[Robert Westall]]'s macabre, and critically appreciated, short story ''Blackham's Wimpy''.<ref>[http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gyggYrpKSXUC&lpg=PA69&ots=dNnuPtWU2u&dq=blackham's%20wimpy&pg=PA71#v=onepage&q&f=false Frightening Fiction By Kimberly Reynolds, Geraldine Brennan, Kevin McCarron]</ref>
==V-22 Osprey== In the 2005 TV [[miniseries]] "[[The Triangle (TV miniseries)|The Triangle]]", V-22 Ospreys armed with torpedoes confront and sink the protagonists' boat on the ocean as they approach the exclusion zone around the temporal phenomenon.<ref name="RotaryActionT" />
Two [[Bell-Boeing V-22 Osprey|Bell-Boeing CV-22 Ospreys]] (of only three in the USAF inventory at the time)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.af.mil/news/story_media.asp?id=123021212 |title=Ospreys in flight |first=Russell |last=Scalf |date=26 May 2006 |publisher=United States Air Force |accessdate= }}</ref> were filmed in flight at [[Holloman Air Force Base]], [[New Mexico]], in May 2006 for the 2007 ''Transformers'' film.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123021221 |title=Movie project transforms Holloman |first=Arlan |last=Ponder |publisher=49th Fighter Wing Public Affairs, United States Air Force |date= 5 June 2006 |accessdate= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123059424 |title= 'Transformers' put Airmen, aircraft on big screen |first=Larry A. |last=Simmons |agency=Air Force News Agency |publisher= United States Air Force |date= 3 July 2007 |accessdate= }}</ref> This would inspire a host of Transformers toys and characters based on the Osprey including the Decepticons [[Incinerator (Transformers)|Incinerator]] and [[Ruination]] as well as the Autobots [[Springer (Transformers)|Springer]] and [[Blades (Transformers)|Blades]].<ref name="AllsparkPower">{{cite web |url= http://www.seibertron.com/news/view.php?id=11280&f_cat=&f_year=&f_keyword=incinerator |title= New Images of Transformers Movie "Allspark Power" Figures, Cliffjumper, Brawl Repaint and More! |accessdate= 2010-01-19 |last= Seibertron.com |authorlink= |year= 2007 |month= July}}</ref>
The ''Transformers 3'' film, filmed at [[Northwest Florida Regional Airport]] and [[Hurlburt Field]], Florida, features the CV-22 Osprey.<ref>[http://www.nwfdailynews.com/news/walton-33344-field-filming.html Transformers 3 filming at airport, Hurlburt Field]</ref>
A V-22 was used to deliver [[John Connor]] to the Resistance's submarine headquarters in ''[[Terminator Salvation]]''.<ref name=Salvation/>
V-22s play prominent roles in several novels by [[Dale Brown]], most particularly, ''Hammerheads'' which features a MV-22 on the cover.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=w3QmgHta0jMC&q=Hammerheads+Dale+Brown&dq=Hammerheads+Dale+Brown&ei=yGssSc6uBozckASdrLGwBQ&pgis=1 |title=Hammerheads |publisher=Berkley Books |year=1991 |first=Dale |last=Born |isbn=0-425-12645-5 |accessdate= 25 November 2008}}</ref>
In the TV series [[Stargate Atlantis|Stargate: Atlantis]], [[John Sheppard (Stargate)|Lt. Colonel John Sheppard]] contrasts flying a V-22 Osprey ''"You had to use your hands and feet with that one."'' to piloting the Ancients' city of Atlantis in the season three finale "[[First Strike (Stargate Atlantis)|First Strike]]". He gives the impression that it will be easier to fly the city - ''"This one you just have to sit down and think... Fly."''<ref>Dialogue with [[Rodney McKay|Dr. Rodney McKay]] during the season three finale ''First Strike''.</ref>
==XB-51== [[File:XB-51.jpg|thumb|right|A [[Martin XB-51]] in ''[[Toward the Unknown]]'']]
The [[Martin XB-51]] depicted the fictional Gilbert XF-120 in the 1956 film ''[[Toward the Unknown]]'' starring [[William Holden]] as a test pilot.<ref>Thompson, Lance, "''Valley of the Kings''", Stamford, Lincs., UK: FlyPast, December 1997, Number 197, p. 25.</ref> On 25 March 1956, the first XB-51 prototype, ''46-0685'', crashed in sand dunes near [[Biggs Army Airfield|Biggs Air Force Base]], [[El Paso, Texas]], killing both crew, while staging to [[Eglin Air Force Base|Eglin AFB]], Florida, for filming of scenes for the motion picture.<ref>Peterson, Wayne. "''Toward The Unknown''". Woodland, Hills, California: Wings, June 2002, Volume 32, Number 3, p. 13.</ref>
==XB-70 Valkyrie== The Transformers character of [[Silverbolt]] was upgraded to a [[North American XB-70 Valkyrie]] for the ''Universe'' line as an Ultra class toy.<ref name="Silverbolt">{{cite web |url= http://www.bwtf.com/toyreviews/universe2/silverbolt |title= Transformers Universe 2.0 Toy Reviews: Silverbolt |accessdate= 2009-12-07 |last= Yee |first= Benson |authorlink= |year= 2009}}</ref>
==Zeppelin== A German [[Zeppelin]] is shot down in the 1930 [[Howard Hughes]] film [[Hell's Angels (film)|''Hell's Angels'']].<ref>[http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9904E7DF1338E433A25755C1A96E9C946194D6CF Hall, Mordaunt, "The Screen", New York Times, 16 August 1930]</ref>
A bombing raid by a Zeppelin comprises a major plot point in the Elsie McCutcheon novel ''Summer of the Zeppelin''.<ref>[http://www.jstor.org/pss/818888 Young Adult Literature - Wars and Rumors of Wars, by Beth Nelms and Ben Nelms]. jstor.org</ref> <!-- Read the notes at top of the edit screen here and top of talk page for this article's criteria for inclusion. -->
In the 1971 British film [[Zeppelin (film)|Zeppelin]] set during WWI, features a new prototype airship.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0068014/ IMDB: Zeppelin]</ref>
